The renovation includes refurbishing the entire east wing, creating public spaces, and restoring the theatre for future theatrical, musical, and cinematic experiences. The project's success relies on raising the remaining funds, with a target reopening date of 2018.

The 30-year-old former Manchester City player, with 61 England caps, has retired from international football. He represented England at two World Cups and two European Championships, but had limited playing time at Euro 2016. Milner, who holds the record for most caps with the England Under-21 team, made his senior debut in 2009 and scored his only international goal in a 2014 World Cup qualifier against Moldova.

Marcy Smith and her family narrowly escaped a devastating house fire in Glovertown, thanks to her son David, who was the only one awake and alerted them to the flames. The fire, caused by burning rubbish in the wood stove, spread rapidly, leaving the family with only their pyjamas. Despite the loss of their home and pets, the community has shown overwhelming support, providing essential items and support. Mrs Smith is incredibly proud of her son's heroic actions, emphasising his crucial role in their survival.

The energy drinks company is rumoured to be interested in buying West Ham United for Â£200 million. The club's current owners, Sullivan and Gold, acquired a majority stake in 2010, valuing the club at Â£105 million. They now own over 85% of the club. West Ham's relocation to the London Stadium has sparked further takeover talks with Qatari and Chinese investors. Despite considering selling a minority share to alleviate debts, Sullivan and Gold plan to pass the club's ownership to their children.

The MTV Movie Awards, a fan-voted ceremony, took place in Los Angeles, showcasing upcoming summer blockbusters. The Fault in Our Stars dominated with multiple wins, including Best Movie and Best Female Performance for Shailene Woodley. Other notable winners were Bradley Cooper, Channing Tatum, Meryl Streep, and Jennifer Lawrence. The event featured emotional speeches, comedic moments, and a preview of summer releases like Pitch Perfect 2 and Marvel's Ultron.

Aberdeen's 21-year-old forward, Cammy Smith, has been loaned to St. Mirren, a move that their boss, Jack Ross, considers a significant addition to the team. Smith has already scored five goals this season during his loan at Dundee United. With his experience and goal-scoring ability, Smith is expected to strengthen St. Mirren's attacking options as they prepare for their upcoming match against Falkirk.

The warm weather in Northumberland has enabled the council to deploy its Jetpatcher machines to repair 145 potholes daily over the next four months. Additional personnel will be assigned to fix drainage systems and clear gutter debris, addressing issues caused by heavy rainfall.

In December 2016, six Wood Group contractors working on EnQuest's Thistle platform off Shetland were exposed to low levels of naturally occurring radioactive material (NORM). The workers, including rigging supervisor Steve Innes, were not wearing proper protective gear as the radiation levels were assumed to be safe. Mr. Innes and his colleagues now face potential health risks and are undergoing blood tests. EnQuest has stated that the exposure was minimal and not reportable, but they have taken additional precautions to ensure worker safety. Wood Group has prioritized employee health and conducted medical assessments, while the Unite union criticizes the handling of the incident, calling for transparency in such matters. The Health and Safety Executive (HSE) was informed but did not investigate as it was not reportable under current regulations.

The Asian Civilisation Museum (ACM) acquired a Hindu goddess sculpture for a significant sum, but it was later revealed to be stolen. The artwork was purchased from a New York dealer, Art of the Past, whose manager confessed to selling looted Indian antiquities. The sculpture is believed to have been stolen from a temple in Tamil Nadu, India. After discussions with the Indian government's Archaeological Survey of India (ASI), ACM decided to return the piece. The museum plans to seek legal compensation for the fraudulent transaction.

A 4.8-magnitude earthquake hit central Italy, causing widespread tremors but no reported injuries or damage. The quake's epicentre was in Garfagnana, north of Lucca, and its impact was felt in cities like Milan, Florence, Bologna, and Modena. Phone and power lines were disrupted in the immediate area. Italy is seismically active, with a history of earthquakes, including a devastating 2009 quake in L'Aquila that killed nearly 300 people. This recent tremor, described as typical for the region, comes as Italy continues to recover from the L'Aquila disaster, which led to the conviction of scientists for providing misleading information about the risk of tremors.

A 62-year-old grandfather from Sheffield, Austin Grant, successfully grew fruit in South Yorkshire's climate, surprising himself and others. The fruit is still attached to the plant and not yet ripe for consumption, but Mr. Grant's achievement is a significant milestone.

Rockstar has delayed the release of their highly anticipated open-world game, originally scheduled for January 27th, until March 24th, to ensure optimal quality. Despite the delay, they announced the addition of online heists for console players before the PC release, with the PC version boasting enhanced graphics. Minimum PC specifications to run the game have been released, and fans eagerly await its launch, following the game's record-breaking sales upon its initial release in 2013.

A 76-year-old artist, previously shortlisted for the John Moores Painting Prize in 1991, has finally won the prestigious award for his painting 'Squint (19)'. The artist, who received Â£25,000, described the win as "very nice". The painting, which depicts a leper squint in a medieval church, was praised by judge Ansel Krut for its subtlety and minimal language, creating a sympathetic atmosphere. The John Moores Painting Prize, established in 1957, has been awarded to renowned artists such as David Hockney and Peter Doig.

Two pro-government newspapers, Yeni Safak and Yeni Akit, were attacked by masked assailants on Thursday morning, resulting in shattered windows and a quickly contained fire at the Yeni Safak building. The offices of these newspapers were targeted due to their support for President Recep Tayyip Erdogan's AK Party. The attacks occurred simultaneously, with the Yeni Akit offices located 20km away from Yeni Safak. Police have secured the areas and are searching for the perpetrators, who remain unidentified. This incident follows a similar attack on the pro-government newspaper Hurriyet in September, where protesters accused the paper of misquoting President Erdogan.

A 24-year-old player has been signed by Marcus Bignot's team on a free transfer, despite being under contract with another club. He spent time on loan at Crawley, scoring three goals, and will join his new team in January as Bignot's inaugural signing.

Arsene Wenger, Arsenal manager, has been linked to the England manager position, currently held by interim manager Gareth Southgate. Wenger praises Southgate's experience and observation skills, but deflects questions about his own potential interest in the role, focusing on his current job. Southgate has upcoming matches against Scotland and Spain to prove his competency and earn the permanent position. Wenger also addresses contract situations, stating that Hector Bellerin will be offered a new deal despite transfer speculation, and providing an update on Aaron Ramsey's injury.

A local man fell from a cherry picker while working at Fruehauf on Houghton Road. The incident occurred at approximately 13:45 GMT on Thursday. Lincolnshire Police, in collaboration with the Health and Safety Executive, is conducting an investigation, and the company is offering full cooperation.

Transport Minister Humza Yousaf announced a new charter arrangement to resolve a dispute over seafarers' pay. The RMT union had raised concerns about low wages on two freight boats, with some workers earning less than Â£4 per hour. The change will bring contracted-out services back to Serco Northlink, the operator, from next month. The freight vessels, Hellier and Hildasay, were previously operated by Seatruck, who argued that the national minimum wage did not apply to the non-UK crew. Serco Northlink offered to address the pay gap, but Seatruck refused. The new arrangement will ensure that all crew members are paid at least the minimum wage, ending the long-running dispute. Serco Northlink holds the Northern Isles contract, operating ferries and cargo boats on a route subsidised by the Scottish government.

Ken Dickie, 64, passed away in hospital six days after an incident at Rockley Park in Poole. Jamie Mitchell, 35, intervened in an argument between Mr. Dickie and his mother, Samantha Mitchell, during a visit on May 7th. The argument escalated into a physical confrontation between Mr. Dickie and Mr. Mitchell, resulting in Mr. Mitchell pleading guilty to common assault. Jamie and Samantha Mitchell also admitted to attempting to pervert the course of justice by providing false accounts of the event to the police. The court case concluded with Jamie Mitchell visibly shaken and the pair awaiting sentencing on February 6th.

Rod Temperton, a renowned British songwriter and musician, passed away at 66 in London due to cancer. Known for his work with Michael Jackson, Heatwave, and other artists, Temperton's career spanned decades. He wrote several hits for Jackson, including "Thriller," "Rock With You," and "Off the Wall," contributing to Jackson's success. Temperton's talent was recognized with a Grammy Award and Oscar nominations. His songs were beloved by many, leaving a significant impact on the music industry. Tributes from musicians and fans alike celebrated his genius and the timeless songs he created.

A team of researchers, including Dr. Neil Loader and Prof. Alayne Street-Perrott from Swansea University, has discovered ancient earthworks in the Brazilian Amazon, estimated to be around 2,000 years old. These earthworks consist of over 450 large geometrical structures called "geoglyphs," hidden for centuries by rainforests until recent deforestation revealed them. The function of these sites remains a mystery, but they are thought to have been used for ritual gatherings rather than as villages or defensive structures. Dr. Loader's analysis of soil samples suggests that the geoglyphs were constructed in tall vegetation, unlike other ritual sites, and were likely not visible above the forest canopy. The research also challenges previous beliefs about the Amazonian forests, indicating human influence through the artificial spread of various plant species over millennia. The team compares the ancient practices to a "prehistoric supermarket" of useful forest products and suggests that modern biodiversity in the region may still reflect these ancient agroforestry techniques.

Nick Kyrgios, the 21-year-old Australian tennis player, defeated Sam Querrey in straight sets to advance to the second round of the Shanghai Masters. Kyrgios, currently ranked 12th in the world, is in top form after winning the Japan Open the previous Sunday. He attributed his unusually subdued behaviour during the match to fatigue from his recent success and travel schedule, which included a long journey to the Qi Zhong Stadium. This is in contrast to his behaviour at the same tournament last year, where he was fined for an expletive-laden tirade.

The HPV vaccine, currently administered to girls aged 12 and 13 to prevent cervical cancer, is advocated by scientists and charities to also protect against head and neck cancers. These groups are urging the Welsh government to extend the vaccination program to boys, citing the increasing incidence of head and neck cancers and the significant role of HPV in global cancer cases. The Welsh government has stated they will await advice from the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation before making any decisions regarding changes to the HPV vaccination program.

Jak Trueman, a 15-year-old cancer patient, passed away from a rare blood cancer, gamma delta T-cell lymphoma. He gained attention for his positive attitude and documented his journey on social media, attracting over 28,000 followers. Jak briefly attended a school prom in his honour but had to leave due to illness. His story inspired many, and his family continues to raise funds for Leukaemia & Lymphoma Research.

In a tight and uneventful game, Egypt secured a late 1-0 win over Uganda thanks to a composed finish by Abdallah El Said, assisted by Mohamed Salah, in the 89th minute. Uganda had a goal disallowed for offside and struggled to create clear-cut chances. The result means Egypt will play Ghana for the top spot in Group D, while Uganda's elimination is confirmed.

The Lancashire County Council has identified potential land for development, including the former Glenburn Sports College and Skelmersdale College sites. A study by Network Rail evaluated these locations, considering a new railway station in Skelmersdale, which has been without one since 1956. The council, in collaboration with Merseytravel and West Lancashire Borough Council, plans to provide direct train services to Liverpool. The chosen site offers room for expansion, easy road access, and good connectivity. The council will now proceed with land acquisition, marking a significant step towards enhancing Skelmersdale's transport infrastructure.
A man in his late 40s was arrested after police discovered an elaborate grow house containing plants during a search of a warehouse near Ashbourne on Saturday morning.

A 28-year-old woman of Kurdish-German origin was found with severe injuries on a pavement in Hamelin, Lower Saxony, on Sunday night. She was dragged by the neck through multiple streets, according to police. The woman's ex-partner, a 38-year-old man also of Kurdish-German origin from Bad Muender, surrendered to the authorities. The victim underwent emergency surgery and was transferred to a specialist clinic. The motive for the attack remains unknown, and police have appealed for witnesses to assist with the investigation.

A study by Cass Business School and the universities of Warwick and Wisconsin has found that women are just as likely as men to ask for a pay rise, but are 25% less likely to receive one. This research, based on data from the 2013-14 Australian workplace relations survey, challenges the "reticent female" theory, as it found no evidence that women were more hesitant to ask for salary increases due to fear of upsetting their boss or deviating from gender stereotypes. The study controlled for various factors like employer size, industry, parenthood, and qualifications, and compared like-for-like male and female workers. Interestingly, it also noted that younger women and men under 40 are negotiating pay more successfully, indicating a potential shift in negotiating behaviour. The findings suggest that there might be an element of pure discrimination against women, according to Professor Andrew Oswald.

The Oxford City Council has been searching for a new burial site, but despite using allocated funds for ground investigations, no suitable location has been found. Two existing cemeteries have limited space and are expected to reach capacity by 2018 and 2021. The council's efforts continue, but suitable land within Oxford is scarce. All identified council-owned sites have been discounted due to various factors like size, ground conditions, water table levels, and covenants. Once the current cemeteries are full, options will be limited to reopening family plots, using reserved plots, and interring ashes. The last expansion of burial space in Oxford occurred in 1932.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival, or HebCelt, is introducing an augmented reality app for visitors to access additional content during the event. The app will allow users to scan items like signs and posters to unlock online information, including videos and band interviews, enhancing the festival experience. This year's festival, taking place in Stornoway, will feature performances by renowned artists such as The Waterboys, Imelda May, and Dougie MacLean. The app will also enable people worldwide to interact with the festival, access information, and purchase tickets remotely, providing a unique and inclusive festival experience.

The 10-year-old racehorse Many Clouds, bred in Ireland, collapsed and died after winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham. The British Horseracing Authority confirmed the cause of death as a severe pulmonary haemorrhage, a rare occurrence in racehorses. Many Clouds had a history of post-race ataxia, causing overheating, but no significant underlying health issues were known. Despite this, questions remain as to whether this condition contributed to his death.

A 34-year-old individual, previously known as David Ayrton and now called Davina, has been found guilty of raping a 15-year-old girl in 2004. The defendant met the victim in a Portsmouth garage and committed the assault while two others were asleep. The victim's recollection of the event was clear, and she reported the attack to a care home worker in 2014. The defendant, who has learning difficulties and has attempted suicide, will be sentenced on March 4th and will likely be held in a male prison. The judge noted the unusual nature of the case and the risk of the defendant failing to attend court if released on bail.

Novak Djokovic and his Serbian partner lost in the men's doubles tennis at the Olympics, following his singles defeat the previous day. This was another setback for Djokovic, who had also lost in the third round of Wimbledon earlier in the summer. Despite these losses, Djokovic is a highly successful tennis player, having won 12 Grand Slam titles and 30 Masters titles.

Over 20 chainsaw carvers will compete in the upcoming event in Carrbridge, Cairngorms, aiming to sculpt logs into animal and human figures. The competition attracts participants from various countries, including Scotland, England, Ireland, continental Europe, Canada, and the US. Last year's champion, Pete Bowsher, will be back to defend his title and the Claymore Trophy.

Rhys Webb, a 27-year-old rugby player, is recovering from a foot injury sustained in September during a World Cup warm-up match against Italy. He is nearing a return to action, aiming to be fit for the Six Nations tournament in February. Webb mentions he is currently in a pre-season training phase and is taking his recovery week by week. Despite offers from other clubs, Webb has decided to renew his contract with his home region, Ospreys, and the Welsh Rugby Union, prioritising his national team ambitions. The Six Nations campaign starts on February 7th with Wales facing Ireland in Dublin.

The US border agents interrupted an attempted drug smuggling operation near Sumas, Washington. Two men, Nathan Hall and Jeffrey Laviolette, were carrying backpacks containing MDMA (ecstasy) from Canada to San Francisco. One man fled after firing at the agents, while Laviolette was arrested. Hall was later apprehended in Canada. The incident led to the arrest of two accomplices, Kali Henifin and Ryan Lambert, who were to receive payment for transporting the drugs. The area is known for smuggling activities, and the defendants face conspiracy and drug-related charges.

The NSPCC's Childline service has seen a significant increase in the number of children seeking help for online abuse and cyberbullying, with over 4,500 cases in the past year. The charity highlights the severe impact of online trolls on children's well-being, with some as young as seven experiencing torment and fear. Dame Esther Rantzen emphasizes the need for adult intervention and school involvement to address this growing issue. The report, released during Anti-Bullying Week, also features advice from young people on coping with bullying.

The US's decision to abstain from vetoing a UN resolution condemning Israeli settlements has caused tension between the two countries. The resolution, which passed on Friday, calls for an end to settlement construction, considering them illegal under international law. This move was prompted by a request from Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's office and comes before US Secretary of State John Kerry's speech on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. Mr. Netanyahu expressed his anger by taking diplomatic actions against the US and other countries that voted in favour. The resolution's impact is felt in Jerusalem, where a vote on new settlement homes was postponed to avoid further straining US-Israel relations ahead of Kerry's speech, which will address the conflict and respond to Israeli criticisms of the Obama administration. Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas sees the resolution as a positive step towards the upcoming Middle East peace conference in France.

The passage describes the celebrations and tributes for Queen Elizabeth II's 90th birthday, including a BBC interview with Prince William, who praised the Queen's dedication to duty and service. The interview also addresses criticisms of William's own commitment to royal duties, with him stating that he takes his responsibilities seriously but aims to find his own path. The Queen's birthday is marked with various events, such as the release of commemorative stamps, a bandstand opening, and a walking trail unveiling. The celebrations are met with enthusiasm by the public and political leaders, but a republican group criticizes the BBC's coverage as excessive.

West Ham United, a Premier League team, defeated Cheltenham Town from League Two 2-0 in the EFL Cup. Diafra Sakho and Andre Ayew scored quick goals before halftime, securing the win. Cheltenham had chances but couldn't capitalize, and the result eliminated League Two teams from the competition before the third round draw.

Aidan McNicholl, a 36-year-old hospital radiographer, was killed in a motorcycle collision on the A5 at Cerrigydrudion. The driver, Andreas Werner, failed to see McNicholl and turned his vehicle, causing the fatal crash. Werner pleaded guilty to careless driving and was fined and banned from driving in the UK for two years. The victim's family did not wish for Werner to be imprisoned, acknowledging it was a momentary lapse in judgement.

Imran Khawaja, a British jihadist who gained notoriety in Syria through online propaganda, returned to the UK and was arrested. He was a member of Rayat al Tawheed, an Islamic State-affiliated group known for sophisticated recruitment tactics targeting young British Muslims. Khawaja's activities in Syria included creating propaganda, soliciting donations, and participating in violent acts, as evidenced by a gruesome photo. His return to the UK was facilitated by his cousin, Tahir Bhatti, who aided his travel. Khawaja attempted to conceal his return and faked his death, but was arrested upon arrival. He is considered highly dangerous and faces life imprisonment for his role in Syria's conflict.

Kayden Jackson, a 22-year-old forward, has signed for Barnsley from Wrexham, where he scored four goals in 36 appearances last season. He is Barnsley's third signing for the upcoming season and is expected to suit their playing style with his pace and directness. Jackson rejected a contract renewal from Wrexham, opting to join Barnsley ahead of their League One play-off final.

Numerous bottles of detergent have washed up on beaches along the Cornish coast, potentially due to a container falling overboard from a ship during stormy weather. The National Trust and other organisations are working to clear the bottles, which pose a risk to wildlife, and advise the public to keep a safe distance.
A crash on the A9 in Caithness resulted in several minor injuries. The road was closed, and diversions were implemented via the A897. Police Scotland is investigating the incident.

Dorian Dervite, a 28-year-old French centre-back, has signed a new contract with Bolton Wanderers after helping the club secure promotion to the Championship. Dervite made 14 appearances last season and has been with Bolton since 2014, making 83 total appearances. His contributions were praised by manager Phil Parkinson, especially towards the end of the campaign. Dervite's contract extension follows those of several other players, ensuring a strong squad for the upcoming Championship season.

The Liberal Democrats and Labour have a history of forming alliances to challenge the government, including on Brexit-related issues. However, tensions arose when the Lib Dems insisted on amendments regarding EU citizens' rights and parliamentary approval for Brexit, while Labour deferred to the Commons. The Lib Dems accused Labour of facilitating a hard Brexit, while Labour criticised the Lib Dems for grandstanding and raising false hopes among EU citizens. Despite these differences, Baroness Ludford from the Lib Dems expressed optimism about future collaboration, while a Labour source predicted residual tensions and a more business-like relationship between the two parties.

The passage discusses the low priority given to defence in the UK's political landscape, despite growing global instability. While the UK's military interventions may have contributed to public fatigue, the main focus is on the significant cuts to the armed forces, with specific examples provided. The article highlights the decreasing defence spending, the potential impact on NATO relations, and the lack of detailed policies from major parties. It mentions the upcoming Strategic Defence Review and the differing views on nuclear deterrence. The text also touches on the challenges of manning new aircraft carriers and the gap between political rhetoric and reality regarding the UK's military capabilities.

Barcelona have paid an additional â¬13.5m in tax for the signing of Neymar, despite denying any wrongdoing. The club's former president, Sandro Rosell, resigned following accusations of misappropriating funds and is under investigation. The total cost of Neymar's transfer and subsequent expenses is estimated to be around Â£106.8m. The player has performed well on the pitch, scoring seven goals in La Liga and three in the Champions League.

Michael Luciw, a 27-year-old father, was killed in a car crash caused by Albert Kenneth Newman, who was driving the wrong way on the motorway. Mr Luciw's family called for regular driving tests for retired people, citing concerns about older drivers' reaction times. The DVLA, however, stated that evidence does not indicate older drivers are more prone to accidents and that current rules require drivers over 70 to renew their licences every three years and disclose medical conditions. Age UK emphasised the importance of supporting older drivers' independence. The incident has sparked a debate about driving regulations for the elderly.

A group of women have raised concerns about the safety of transvaginal mesh implants used to treat incontinence, with some experiencing severe side effects. The original review group's report was criticised, leading to the appointment of independent expert Professor Alison Britton to examine the review process and its conclusions. The report recommended against routine use of the implants for pelvic organ prolapse and emphasised informed patient choices. Despite calls for a ban, the Scottish government stated it lacked the authority, as it falls under the UK's Medicines and Healthcare Products Regulatory Agency. The review's chair, Tracey Gillies, apologised for the lack of consensus among panel members. Two patients and a consultant resigned from the review group due to disagreements with the final report. Over 20,000 Scottish women have received these implants, with some experiencing complications, and over 400 are taking legal action.

Laura Muir, aged 23, broke Liz McColgan's 25-year-old 5K record by 14 seconds with a time of 14 minutes and 49.12 seconds. McColgan, while initially questioning the validity of the record due to the nature of the race, later praised Muir's performance and her potential to win world medals. Muir's race strategy and her status as a fellow Scot were also highlighted by McColgan. Muir has demonstrated her talent in middle-distance running, breaking the British 1500m record and reaching the Olympic final.

Jung, riding Sam, won the competition, with Astier Nicolas and Phillip Dutton claiming silver and bronze respectively. William Fox-Pitt, a three-time Olympic medallist, finished 12th despite a strong show-jumping performance, due to time penalties in the cross-country phase. The article also promotes a fan experience with a mechanical horse and encourages readers to subscribe to a newsletter for equestrian sports.

Andy Murray, a 30-year-old British tennis player, defeated Fabio Fognini in a tense and dramatic match at Wimbledon, securing a spot in the fourth round. The match lasted over two hours, with Murray winning in four sets. Fognini, the 29th seed, had opportunities to force a fifth set but Murray's resilience and a late surge secured his victory. The match was characterised by Fognini's fluctuating performance, an ankle injury, and on-court controversies. Murray will next face Benoit Paire, while fellow Briton Johanna Konta also advanced to the second week.

Paramedics and police were called to Joe's Bar in Dungiven, where alcohol was served outside licensing hours. The bar owner, Colleen O'Neill, and James Thomas were charged with allowing liquor consumption after hours. The judge ordered the bar's closure for three months, citing O'Neill's poor record, and imposed fines of Â£3,000 and Â£1,000 respectively.

Mike Nesbitt, in his speech launching the Ulster Unionist Party's manifesto, emphasized the importance of partnership over domination, specifically referring to the Renewable Heat Incentive debacle. He faced questions about his comments on voting for other parties, which caused a stir, but he stood by his statement. Nesbitt expressed confidence in his position and highlighted the party's focus on issues like healthcare, policing, infrastructure, and LGBT rights. The manifesto, 'Real Partnership', also addresses Stormont's governance and calls for action against corruption. The election, according to Nesbitt, should be a referendum on the DUP-Sinn FÃ©in coalition's performance, including their handling of the RHI scandal.

The Justice Minister of Northern Ireland, Claire Sugden, has confirmed plans to introduce a motion for automatic pardons for gay and bisexual men convicted of historical sexual offences. This move mirrors recent proposals in England and Wales, known as 'Turing's Law', which aims to posthumously pardon those convicted of now-abolished sexual offences and allow living individuals to apply for pardons. The minister has secured executive agreement to seek legislative consent, ensuring equal treatment for gay and bisexual men in Northern Ireland. The motion will be presented to the assembly for approval, offering an opportunity to rectify past injustices within the criminal justice system.

Laura Muir, a 23-year-old Scottish athlete, achieved a new Scottish record in the 1500m race, finishing second behind Kenyan Faith Kipyegon. This performance surpassed Yvonne Murray's previous Scottish record and placed Muir second on the British all-time list. Muir, who also holds the Scottish mile record, expressed her excitement about her first race of the season at this distance and her close competition with Kipyegon. She aims to secure an Olympic spot for Great Britain at the upcoming British trials in Birmingham. Muir's recent success comes as she balances her veterinary studies, having completed her fourth year of vet school.
A collection of pictures showcases 26 Scottish beaches renowned for their exceptional water quality, earning the title of "most excellent".

A Met Police barrister, Richard Horwell QC, argued that the Russian state was likely behind the murder of Mr. Alexander Litvinenko, a former KGB officer who defected to the UK. Mr. Litvinenko died from a fatal dose of radioactive polonium-210, which he ingested during a meeting with two suspects, Dmitry Kovtun and Andrei Lugovoi. The barrister emphasized the suspects' connection to Russia and their lack of a personal motive, suggesting state involvement. However, he clarified that this does not directly implicate President Vladimir Putin. The case highlights the challenges of extradition and the potential risks posed by radioactive substances in a public setting.

Steve Smith, aged 26, has been appointed as the new captain of the Australian cricket team for both the one-day and Twenty20 formats, replacing the retired Michael Clarke. Smith, who has previously captained the Test side against India, is praised for his talent and leadership skills. David Warner, 28, has been named as vice-captain, despite past disciplinary issues, as the selectors believe he has matured and will embrace the leadership role. The new leadership duo will take charge after the final Ashes Test against England.

A political leader, Mr Farron, has expressed his support for LGBT+ rights and equal marriage, despite refusing to answer questions about his personal beliefs on homosexual sex. He aims to defend and extend marital rights for the LGBT+ community, particularly for transgender individuals who currently face challenges due to the spousal veto. Mr Farron's voting record on the Equality Bill in 2007 has been questioned, but he asserts his commitment to equality and individual liberties.

Accord Healthcare is set to reopen a former Sanofi drug manufacturing site in Fawdon, aiming to employ many ex-Sanofi staff. This move is expected to positively impact the local economy, as Accord is a significant player in the pharmaceutical industry, offering highly skilled jobs and long-term investment. The company produces and distributes a wide range of pharmaceutical products globally.

The local council is experiencing a significant turnover in its senior leadership, with three key figures departing. Richard Ellis, the former interim director of corporate governance and acting deputy chief executive, is leaving at the end of his contract. Ciaran Monaghan, head of the chief executive's office, and Ewan Sutherland, head of human resources and customer services, are both taking voluntary redundancy and early retirement. The leader of the opposition SNP group, Stephen Flynn, criticizes the council's inability to retain senior staff and predicts more departures. Angela Scott, the council chief executive, expressed gratitude for the departing staff's contributions.

Michael Martin, an English rider, experienced a crash at the TT and faced issues with his Fireblade bike. He initially announced his retirement from road racing but later clarified that he would not race on Hondas this year. Martin skipped the North West 200 and will not participate in the upcoming Ulster Grand Prix due to the bike's lack of competitiveness. He expressed his desire to focus on classic and unique racing events.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) secured a significant victory in the recent elections, claiming 19 out of 28 governor posts. This marks a major setback for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP), which has dominated Nigerian politics since 1999. The PDP's decline is evident in key northern states and the loss of control in Adamawa, a state affected by Boko Haram. The APC's success relegates the PDP to a regional party, with the latter failing to secure a national vote. The elections were marked by violence in some areas due to intense rivalry and ethnic tensions, but overall, Nigeria's democracy appears to be maturing with a more peaceful electoral process. The PDP's defeat can be attributed to factors such as corruption allegations, defections, and the perception that it was time for a change after 16 years in power.

An environmental group, Mighty, has accused the agricultural commodities trader Olam and its main stakeholder, Temasek, of being linked to unsustainable palm oil practices in Indonesia, which contribute to the annual haze affecting Southeast Asian countries. Mighty's report claims that Olam creates a market for palm oil from unknown sources, potentially encouraging rogue traders. Olam denies these allegations, stating they have strict sourcing policies against burning and deforestation. The company has a small market share and buys mostly from third-party suppliers, making supplier policing challenging. Temasek, a Singapore state-owned company, also refutes the claims, stating they support no-burn policies. The palm oil industry is massive and often criticized for labour issues and environmental damage, with activists calling for government action. Mighty further alleges that Olam's operations in Gabon involve deforestation, which Olam counters by emphasizing their commitment to responsible and transparent practices.
A restaurant has introduced a puppy platter to its menu, allowing dogs to dine outdoors following a new law permitting dogs in restaurants.

Fernando Forestieri is a doubt for the upcoming game due to a knee injury, while David Nugent may return from a groin injury. Jacob Butterfield is also in contention for a starting spot after his impressive substitute appearance in the previous match.

Pakistan's ban on YouTube, imposed in 2012 due to the controversial film "Innocence of Muslims," has been lifted. The Pakistan Telecommunication Authority (PTA) directed internet service providers to open access after Google launched a Pakistan-specific version of YouTube. Google has provided a process for blocking offensive content, but YouTube denies automatic compliance with government requests for removal. The lifting of the ban has been welcomed, but some activists seek transparency regarding the deal between Google and the Pakistani government.

Domenico Scala, the head of FIFA's Ad-Hoc Electoral Committee, is facing a potential conflict of interest due to his shared nationality with presidential candidate Gianni Infantino. Musa Bility, the LFA boss, has threatened to take legal action if Scala does not withdraw from the committee by Thursday. Scala and another committee member, Claudio Sulser, previously stepped aside during the 2015 elections between Sepp Blatter and Prince Ali due to similar nationality concerns. However, Scala's spokesperson argues that there is no conflict of interest this time as there is no incumbent president among the five candidates. Bility has demanded an explanation for the change in process and has threatened to challenge the decision if Scala does not step down. The upcoming election, with five candidates, will be voted on by FIFA's members and is set to replace the long-standing president, Sepp Blatter.

Two men, Daniel Timbers and Barry Joy, were killed in a flashover explosion at Harford Attachments, a company that manufactures buckets for diggers. The explosion occurred in a paint-spraying area, resulting from a build-up of toxic fumes and subsequent ignition, causing a fireball. Forensic investigations and witness statements have been collected, indicating significant progress in the inquiry. The Health and Safety Executive is also involved, with inspectors and electrical safety experts gathering evidence.

The 2017 Africa Cup of Nations saw both Tunisia and Morocco face challenges to their participation. Tunisia was initially threatened with expulsion due to complaints against the organising body, Caf, but an apology averted this. Morocco's entry was secured after a ban was overturned by the Court of Arbitration for Sport (Cas). Morocco's FA president expressed optimism for the future, downplaying the impact of their temporary exclusion. The nation was previously fined and banned for refusing to host the 2015 Nations Cup over Ebola fears. This incident also involved Tunisia, who disputed a penalty decision in their 2015 quarter-final loss to the hosts, Equatorial Guinea, leading to a demand for an apology from Caf. Tunisia's qualification for the 2017 tournament was confirmed after a reconciliation meeting, with the Tunisian Football Federation denying accusations of corruption. Tunisia aims for a record 13th consecutive Nations Cup appearance.

A mass fracas occurred in the final minutes of the game between Manchester City and Chelsea, resulting in red cards for City's Sergio Aguero and Fernandinho. Aguero received a four-match ban for violent conduct, while Fernandinho got a three-match ban for his involvement in the scuffle. Chelsea's Cesc Fabregas will face no further action. Pep Guardiola apologised for his team's role in the incident. Both clubs have a deadline to respond to the charge.

England secured a dominant victory against Pakistan in the second Test match of the series at Old Trafford, winning by a significant margin of runs. The team's performance was led by Joe Root, who excelled in all aspects of the game. Root's impressive batting, including a double century and a quick-fire unbeaten half-century, earned him the man-of-the-match award. His performance at number three was highly praised by the England captain, Alastair Cook, and coach Trevor Bayliss. The Pakistan team struggled, with only their captain Misbah-ul-Haq and Asad Shafiq showing some resistance. Former England batsman Geoffrey Boycott suggested that Pakistan's spirit was broken, and predicted further wins for England in the series. However, despite the comprehensive victory, Michael Vaughan cautioned that the series would be closely contested.

Warren Gatland, the head coach of the British and Irish Lions, has chosen Rob Howley as an interim coach for the team's tour in New Zealand. Robin McBryde, the forwards coach, will step up as head coach for this tour, a role he has fulfilled twice before. The Welsh Rugby Union will appoint assistant coaches to support McBryde. The WRU is in talks with potential candidates and aims to finalise the management team soon. The involvement of Welsh coaches in the Lions tour is seen as a valuable opportunity for their development, which will ultimately benefit Welsh rugby as a whole.

Charlie Austin's early penalty put Southampton in control against Hull City, who lost two starting strikers to injury in the first half. Hull's Robert Snodgrass, returning from injury, equalised in the second half and then assisted Michael Dawson's header for the winner. Southampton pushed for an equaliser but Hull's defence, including a remarkable goalline clearance by Sam Clucas, held firm. The win ends Hull's losing streak but they remain in the bottom three.

A motorcyclist was killed in a collision with a tractor on the B1191 at Thornton, near Woodhall Spa. The incident occurred around 14:15 BST, and the police have requested witnesses to come forward. The road was temporarily closed in both directions between the B1192 Tattershall Road junction and the A158 Jubilee Way junction.

President Ivanov of Macedonia cancelled an investigation into allegations of abuse of power, citing the need to protect national interests and end the country's turmoil. This decision was met with criticism from the opposition leader, Zoran Zaev, who called it illegal and urged protests, as well as from EU officials, who stated that it contradicted the rule of law and jeopardised Macedonia's EU membership aspirations. The crisis began with the release of covert recordings in 2015, which allegedly exposed ministerial corruption, vote-rigging, and the cover-up of a murder. Zaev has been releasing additional recordings, alleging widespread government corruption, while the government denies the charges and accuses Zaev of attempting to destabilise the country.

Swansea City's assistant manager, Curtis, will temporarily take charge of the team alongside Paul Williams following Bob Bradley's dismissal. The club aims to swiftly appoint a new manager, with Paul Clement as their top choice. Swansea, promoted to the Premier League in 2011, is concerned about potential relegation and the challenges of returning to the top tier. Curtis attributes their struggles to frequent managerial changes and the loss of key players, believing they've strayed from the 'Swansea Way'. He remains confident in the current squad's ability to avoid relegation, emphasizing the club's remarkable journey to the players.

The passage describes a crucial football match between Dagenham & Redbridge (The Daggers) and Leyton Orient (The O's) with significant implications for both teams. Dagenham, facing relegation, needed a win to maintain their League Two status, while Orient aimed to secure a play-off spot. The game saw a dramatic turnaround as Dagenham initially conceded two goals but fought back to level the score. However, Armand Gnanduillet's winner for Orient sealed Dagenham's fate, relegating them to the National League. This marks a disappointing season for Dagenham, who have struggled defensively and offensively compared to previous campaigns. Despite the setback, Dagenham's manager, John Still, remains committed to leading the team back to the Football League next season. Meanwhile, Orient's interim manager, Andy Hessenthaler, expressed relief at the win, acknowledging the challenges of losing two managers in a season and the importance of professionalism and fan support.

Steven Gerrard, the former Liverpool captain and ex-England international, will return to Liverpool as a youth coach in February, marking his first role since retiring as a player. Jurgen Klopp, the current Liverpool manager, expressed his support for Gerrard's appointment, revealing Gerrard's ambition to become a manager in the future. Gerrard, who had a successful playing career with Liverpool and LA Galaxy, is currently working towards his UEFA A coaching license, a requirement for managing in the Premier League. He was previously linked with the managerial position at MK Dons but felt it was too soon in his coaching journey.
Morton defeated Alloa in a football match with a final score of 4-1. McManus and Johnstone scored two goals each for Morton, while McAusland scored Alloa's only goal.

In Birmingham, England, Ofsted has discovered and closed down three illegal schools operating in squalid conditions, with the owners currently under investigation. These schools were primarily located in Muslim communities in the Midlands, and there are concerns that children were at risk of abuse or radicalisation. Sir Michael Wilshaw, Chief Inspector of Schools, believes this issue is widespread and has criticised the government for not taking quicker action. The government has since provided funding for inspectors to investigate these illegal schools, and the Education Secretary has consented to prosecute unregistered schools. The consultation on further regulation of part-time education centres and 'flexi schools' is ongoing until mid-January.

Lilliard Gin is a small-scale distillery located in Jedburgh, aiming to showcase the local flavours and terroir of the Scottish Borders. It is the first gin distillery in the region and a precursor to upcoming whisky distilleries, with the potential to establish the Borders as a distilling excellence hub. The gin's name honours a local legend, Lilliard, a female warrior from the Battle of Ancrum Moor, reflecting the distillery's strong female production team and connection to the local history and landscape. The distillery's unique selling point is its use of local botanicals, aligning with the philosophy of local sourcing at the Born in the Borders visitor centre.

Harry Whitlam was killed in August 2013 when Gary Green, who was heavily intoxicated, reversed a tractor into him at Swithens Farm. Green, who was on private land, was more than twice the legal driving limit, having consumed the equivalent of 13 pints of beer. He was sentenced to 16 months and two weeks in jail for failing to ensure the safety of others, as the incident was prosecuted under health and safety laws. Harry's mother, Pam Whitlam, expressed her grief and emphasized the impact of the tragedy on their close-knit family, hoping to remember the good times they shared with Harry.

Luis Suarez, a 27-year-old Uruguayan striker, has been granted permission to train and participate in friendly matches by the Court of Arbitration for Sport (Cas), despite his initial ban from all football-related activities. The ban was imposed by FIFA following Suarez's biting incident with Giorgio Chiellini during the 2014 World Cup. Suarez's lawyers appealed the decision, arguing that the punishment was excessive and that FIFA misapplied its rules. While Cas upheld most of the sanctions, they agreed that preventing Suarez from training would have an impact on his post-suspension performance. Suarez can now train with his new club, Barcelona, and play in upcoming Uruguay friendlies. However, he will still serve the remaining eight games of his international ban and is likely to make his competitive Barcelona debut in El Clasico against Real Madrid. The full Cas ruling will be published later, and the decision has sparked discussions about proportionality in disciplinary sanctions, especially for repeat offenders like Suarez.

Richard Blake-Smith and Anna won a race in which competitors must carry their partner through a challenging obstacle course. They beat Vytautas Kirkliauskas and his wife, Neringa Kirliauskiene, from Lithuania. The race included various pairings, and the winners will now represent their country at the World Championships in Finland.

Stephen Hammond, a government minister, addressed concerns about potential job losses at the DVLA in Swansea East due to the upcoming transition from paper tax discs to an electronic system. In a letter to local AM Mike Hedges, Mr. Hammond explained that while job roles might change and some tasks may decrease, the government aims to manage any staff reductions through redeployment rather than redundancies. Mr. Hedges welcomed this assurance, acknowledging the benefits of the new system while expressing disappointment about the potential decrease in job opportunities at the DVLA.

The EU and Hungary are in a dispute over Hungary's domestic policies. The EU objects to Hungary's strict regulations on asylum seekers, NGOs, and a higher education law. The education law, in particular, may lead to the closure of the Central European University, founded by George Soros. Hungary's government, led by Viktor Orban, refuses to back down, stating that these are domestic matters. Poland has pledged to veto any EU sanctions against Hungary, which requires unanimous approval from member countries. Hungary's treatment of asylum seekers and the potential impact on the CEU have raised concerns about EU law compliance. Human rights groups also worry that draft legislation on NGOs will negatively label them. The EU has threatened action if Hungary does not make changes, but Hungary remains defiant.

Emma Watson will star as Belle in the live-action remake of Beauty and the Beast, alongside Dan Stevens as the Beast, Kevin Kline as Belle's father Maurice, and Emma Thompson as Mrs. Potts. The film, directed by Bill Condon, will also feature Luke Evans as Gaston, Josh Gad as LeFou, and will be released in US cinemas in March 2017.

Adrian Gill, a renowned columnist and author, passed away after a battle with cancer. Known for his witty and fearless writing style, Gill was a prominent figure at the Sunday Times, where he had worked since 1993. Despite his illness, Gill maintained a positive outlook, feeling fortunate and not cheated by life. His final column, reflecting on his diagnosis, will be published posthumously. Tributes poured in from fellow writers, journalists, and broadcasters, praising Gill's exceptional writing talent, compassion, and kindness. However, Gill's writing also sparked controversy at times, particularly with his provocative descriptions and reviews.

A Mongolian rapper, Amarmandakh Sukhbaatar, was allegedly attacked during a performance in Ulan Bator, where he wore a traditional Mongolian robe with a swastika emblem. Russian news reports claimed he was assaulted with a bottle and kicked, resulting in a coma. The swastika, an ancient symbol in Mongolia, predates its association with the Nazis. Sukhbaatar's father confirmed the severity of his son's injuries, while the Russian embassy disputed local press accounts. The rapper's lawyer demanded an investigation, and a police spokesman confirmed the suspect's diplomatic status but denied immunity as the reason for his release.

Plane Stupid campaigners protested against airport expansion, leading to charges of aggravated trespass and entering a restricted area. The protest occurred on Monday at 03:30 BST on the northern runway, and the demonstrators will face court on 19 August. The Metropolitan Police will review airport security following the incident.

Glamorgan's innings was led by Nick Selman's century, his second in first-class cricket, despite being dropped early on. Seam bowlers Matt Taylor and Craig Miles took regular wickets, restricting the total to 220. Gloucestershire's reply was challenging due to the bowling-friendly conditions, and the match ended the day evenly poised. Selman's form returned after a difficult period, while Taylor was pleased with his bowling performance and the opportunity to play with the red ball.

Craig Hughes, a 33-year-old man from Flint, was arrested for making online threats to kill police officers in a planned ambush. He admitted to these charges in court and will be sentenced soon. Hughes intended to lure officers to the Dee Estuary with a false report and then shoot them. These threats were made while he was intoxicated, and he had a prior conviction for firearm possession. Despite his legal team's claims, the police took the threats seriously due to Hughes's history with firearms offences.

The match saw a strong performance from Surrey, who posted an impressive score of 255-7 after an early setback, thanks to a crucial partnership between Davies and Foakes. Yorkshire's run-chase was hindered by Stuart Meaker's three-wicket burst, which included key wickets. Despite a fighting effort from Tim Bresnan and Matthew Waite, Yorkshire fell short, all out for 236. Surrey's captain, Gareth Batty, praised his team's performance, highlighting the pivotal partnership and effective bowling. Yorkshire's captain, Alex Lees, expressed disappointment, acknowledging their strong bowling but lamenting their inability to deliver in crucial moments.

The crew of a converted trawler radioed for help as they were taking on water 6 miles west of South Stack. The coastguards responded, and the RNLI lifeboat crew assisted by providing a pump and towing the vessel to Holyhead.

Laura Muir, a 24-year-old Scottish middle-distance runner, will miss the 2018 Commonwealth Games on Australia's Gold Coast due to her veterinary medicine exams in May. Despite her disappointment, she prioritises completing her degree. Muir reflects on her recent success at the World Athletics Championships, finishing fourth and sixth in the 1500m and 5000m, respectively, and achieving a new outdoor personal best. She expresses her happiness with her performance and looks forward to the World Indoor Championships in March, considering it a potential target.

Robbie Savage discusses Liverpool's current struggles in the Premier League, their chances of finishing in the top four, and the challenges facing manager Brendan Rodgers. He highlights the team's overachievement last season, the loss of key players, and the need for improvement in various areas, including defence and set-pieces. Savage also mentions Steven Gerrard's mental battle to recover from his slip against Chelsea and his potential future at the club.

A new Â£45 million facility in Kilmarnock will be named after the late writer William McIlvanney. The campus will include schools, a Gaelic school, and a childcare centre. McIlvanney, a renowned author, educator, and influential figure in Scottish culture, was born and educated in Kilmarnock. He is known for his Glasgow-based novels and his contribution to various literary and media forms. The council aims to honour his legacy and his passion for education by naming the campus after him.

A British sea mine, believed to be from the 1940s or 1950s, was discovered near the town of Gourock, leading to a partial evacuation of the area. Three streets were evacuated, and residents within 500m were advised to stay indoors near walls and open windows. An exclusion zone was set up on the river and at sea, disrupting ferry services and small boat operations. The mine's deterioration prevented experts from determining the amount of explosive material inside, so it was moved to a safer location before being made safe. The local authorities emphasised that the evacuation was a precautionary measure, and thanked residents for their cooperation.

The UK government and National Lottery have allocated Â£345 million in funding for 31 Olympic and Paralympic sports, with the aim of maintaining Britain's success from the Rio 2016 Games. This funding decision has impacted various sports, with some experiencing cuts and others being added for the Tokyo 2020 Games. Cycling, despite its success in Rio, has seen a significant funding reduction. Badminton, which earned a medal in Rio, has had its funding removed, prompting criticism from Badminton England and questions about the decision-making process. Judo, on the other hand, received a slight funding increase despite a similar medal outcome as badminton. UK Sport defends its decisions, prioritizing medal potential, while acknowledging the need for further exploration of funding for additional sports.

The Bournemouth council has approved plans to demolish three Victorian hotels and replace them with a modern hotel and assisted-living apartments at East Cliff, despite strong objections from English Heritage and residents. The decision was made to boost tourism and improve living standards for older residents. The new development will feature a 90-room hotel and 122 assisted-living apartments, but concerns have been raised about the potential harm to the conservation area's historic character.

Pte Matthew Boyd, an off-duty soldier, was brutally attacked and killed by Jake Vallely during a night out in Brecon. Vallely, who had been on a drinking binge, punched and beat Pte Boyd, leaving him unconscious. The incident was captured on CCTV, showing the severity of the assault. Vallely will be sentenced for the murder, while his friend Aaeron Evans was cleared of any involvement. The attack shocked the community, and the victim's family paid tribute to Pte Boyd, describing him as a loving and caring individual whose life and career were tragically cut short.

Andrew Travers, the chief executive of Barnet Council, stepped down by mutual agreement following an error that led to voters being turned away from polling stations due to missing names on the poll list. An independent investigation has been launched, and the council will review the appropriateness of arrangements for the upcoming EU Referendum. The council apologised and offered emergency proxy votes to affected residents, but voters questioned the fairness of the election process.

The football match between Gateshead and Wrexham ended 2-1 to the home side. Gateshead took the lead through a Josh Gillies free-kick, but Wrexham equalised before half-time with a Sean Newton set-piece. In the second half, Ryan Bowman scored the winner for Gateshead with a header. The Gateshead manager praised his team's performance, especially in the second half, while the Wrexham manager was disappointed with the result, feeling they should have taken more of their chances.
The Global AgeWatch Index 2014 ranks the social and economic well-being of the elderly in 96 countries, with Norway leading and Afghanistan and Mozambique at the bottom.

A new network of satellites, initially comprising 600 spacecraft and potentially expanding to over 2,000, aims to provide global broadband coverage, with a focus on connecting schools. This project, led by OneWeb and Airbus, introduces innovative assembly line methods to manufacture satellites at a lower cost and higher volume. The traditional approach to satellite construction, often involving high costs and long lead times, is being challenged. The Toulouse assembly line, with its trolley robot, marks a significant shift in satellite production. The OneWeb constellation's launch plan is ambitious, requiring the largest rocket campaign in spaceflight history, with over 20 Soyuz vehicles booked. The project has raised $1.7 billion in equity and is seeking loans for completion. OneWeb's commitment to debris mitigation includes de-orbiting satellites within two years and implementing additional safety measures. This venture aims to disrupt the satellite industry, but traditional bespoke satellite construction will still be necessary for certain missions.

Mr Swinney, the Scottish government's finance secretary, criticises the UK government's spending review for imposing significant cuts on Scotland's budget, amounting to a 12.5% reduction by 2019-20. He argues that these cuts are unnecessary and will impact essential services like schools, hospitals, and police. The UK government counters that Scotland will have more spending power and benefits from the stability of the UK economy. Labour's Jackie Baillie calls for a long-term budget with a real alternative to austerity, criticising the Scottish government's self-congratulatory tone.

The passage highlights the need for Changing Places toilets, which are more accessible than standard disabled toilets, to support individuals with severe disabilities and their carers. These toilets provide extra features and space to accommodate those who require two carers or a hoist for transfers. While recommendations exist for installing Changing Places in larger buildings, campaigners advocate for making them compulsory in new constructions, particularly in shopping centres, cinemas, and sports stadiums. The lack of these facilities can lead to feelings of isolation and stress for families, impacting their ability to engage in everyday activities. The article includes personal stories from families affected by the lack of Changing Places and highlights the positive impact of having accessible spaces for outings and events. It also discusses the challenges businesses face when retrofitting these toilets and the importance of considering all customers' needs.

A group of Italian consumer organisations has filed a formal complaint against McDonald's with the European Commission, alleging that the company exploits its franchisees through excessive rents and fees. McDonald's defends its practices, stating that it shares risks and rewards with franchisees. The complaint is supported by international and European unions, who argue that McDonald's abuses its market power, harming franchisees, consumers, and workers. The European Commission will review the complaint and has the authority to launch an investigation. The consumer groups claim that long-term contracts and above-market-rate leases restrict franchisees' freedom, resulting in reduced consumer choice and higher prices in franchised stores compared to company-owned outlets. With franchisees operating 73% of McDonald's European restaurants, the company generated significant revenue from its franchised restaurants globally in 2014.

A social media campaign using the hashtag #prayforjosh has gained global attention to support 13-year-old Joshua Martin, who was diagnosed with cancer. The campaign originated from Bangor Elim Church, where Josh's father works, and has since gone viral, leading to a billboard being erected in Holywood. The church's pastor, Gary Beattie, expressed surprise at the widespread support, which has included a mystery donor funding the billboard. The campaign has brought worldwide attention to Josh's story, with his classmates and people from County Down showing their support.

The UK government's decision to close Brecon Barracks has sparked controversy, with local MP Chris Davies strongly opposing the move. The barracks, with a rich history dating back to 1805, has been a significant military site, contributing to various conflicts. Davies highlights the potential impact on the town's military tourism and unemployment rates. The closure is part of a wider military reorganisation in Wales, which includes the creation of a specialist centre at St Athan and the delayed closure of Cawdor Barracks. Labour's Shadow Defence Secretary, Nia Griffith, supports restructuring but expresses concern for affected communities.

The passage discusses the potential impact of Brexit on the UK fishing industry. It highlights the concerns of fishing communities, who fear being marginalized in the Brexit negotiations, as they strongly supported leaving the EU due to the perceived negative effects of the Common Fisheries Policy (CFP). The House of Lords report acknowledges the industry's low economic contribution but emphasizes its importance to local communities, urging the government not to neglect it. The report also mentions the complexities of shared fish stocks and the need for continued market access, which might require compromises in access to UK waters. While some in the fishing industry remain optimistic about post-Brexit opportunities, the report suggests retaining certain elements of the CFP and highlights potential challenges regarding fisheries management in different UK regions. The EU's announcement of new quotas is seen positively by some industry representatives, who believe it bodes well for British fishing outside the EU.

Edward Snowden, a former CIA technical worker, leaked classified information to the Guardian, exposing the US government's extensive surveillance capabilities. The leaks revealed the National Security Agency's (NSA) access to various personal data, including chat logs, stored data, and social media activity. The US government confirmed requesting phone records from Verizon, sparking debates about data protection and privacy. Experts question the true extent of the surveillance, with some suggesting it may be more limited than initially believed. The US Patriot Act of 2001 grants American authorities access to European data stored in the US, raising concerns about data protection laws and government surveillance. The existence of the Prism program, which provides the US government with access to data from major tech companies, has been a significant concern for privacy advocates. Edward Snowden's actions were motivated by his desire to protect privacy and prevent mass surveillance.

A group of prominent technology companies and entrepreneurs, including Elon Musk, Peter Thiel, and Amazon Web Services, have backed Open AI, a venture dedicated to advancing artificial intelligence (AI) research for the benefit of humanity. The backers aim to provide financial support without imposing financial obligations, allowing Open AI to focus on positive human impact. While some experts like Elon Musk and Stephen Hawking have warned about the potential threats of AI to humanity, others argue that the risk is remote. Open AI's mission is to develop AI in a way that benefits society as a whole, ensuring it is an extension of human will and widely distributed. The organization plans to use only a small portion of the pledged $1 billion in the initial years.

Ben Parkinson, a former soldier who suffered a severe brain injury in Afghanistan, gained widespread attention after carrying the Olympic torch in 2006. Despite his injuries, he demonstrated resilience and a positive attitude, inspiring thousands on social media. Facebook's friend limit prevented him from accepting all friend requests, but his story and determination resonated with many, leading to an outpouring of support and a significant increase in engagement for the Pilgrim Bandits charity.

In 2011, the poverty rate in the US remained at 15%, affecting 46.2 million Americans, with a median income decline of 1.5%. The poverty threshold for a family of four was $23,021, and income inequality rose for the first time since 1993. Despite a decrease in uninsured Americans, poverty levels reached a record high of 15.1% in 2010.

Jos Buttler, a 25-year-old cricketer, has extended his contract with Lancashire County Cricket Club until 2019. He is renowned for his ODI batting records and his contributions to the team's success in the T20 Blast. Ashley Giles, the cricket director, praised Buttler's talent and impact on the team. After playing in the Indian Premier League, Buttler will rejoin Lancashire for their upcoming match against Durham.

Several decommissioned Type 22 frigates are up for sale and are currently docked in Portsmouth Harbour. The government aims to sell at least one frigate to a UK ship recycler to assess the industry's capabilities. MP Penny Mordaunt advocates for preserving at least one frigate, preferably as a reef and diving attraction, to honour their military service and provide tourism benefits. The Ministry of Defence seeks the best financial return for taxpayers, considering all options for the frigates' disposal. The Type 22 frigates were versatile warships with advanced capabilities, making them valuable assets during their operational lifespan.

Fiji has experienced significant political instability and racial tensions since 1987, marked by multiple coups and power struggles between indigenous Fijians and Indo-Fijians. These events, including the 2000 coup led by George Speight, have damaged the economy and Fiji's international standing. The country was suspended from the Commonwealth in 2009 due to democratic setbacks but was reinstated after holding free elections in 2014. Fiji's population is divided between indigenous Fijians and Indo-Fijians, with minimal mixing and deep-rooted segregation. Despite a diverse economy, Fiji struggles with trade and budget deficits, relying heavily on foreign aid.

The Syrian government, represented by Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad, claims they are making efforts to comply with the timetable for destroying their chemical weapons, despite missing a recent deadline. They attribute the delay to security issues, specifically an attack on a shipment of weapons en route to the port of Latakia. Mr. Mekdad criticized the US for condemning their use of barrel bombs in Aleppo, denying civilian targets, and accused them of supporting terrorists. The Syrian government also refuted reports of rebels capturing Aleppo's central prison, which is said to hold thousands of detainees in poor conditions. The US and Russia, a Syrian ally, have expressed concern over the delays, with Russia setting a new deadline for the transfer of chemical weapons. The Organisation for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons (OPCW) acknowledged security concerns as a reason for the slow progress.

The Booker Prize, in its 46th year, has a shortlist of six novels, including The Lives of Others by Mukherjee, J by former winner Howard Jacobson, How To Be Both by Ali Smith, To Rise Again at a Decent Hour by Joshua Ferris, We Are All Completely Beside Ourselves by Karen Joy Fowler, and The Narrow Road to the Deep North by Richard Flanagan. The winner will be announced in London, with the strongest contender being Mukherjee's novel, which has seen a sales boost post-nomination. However, critics argue that the list is weak and that Jacobson's J, despite its merits, may be overlooked due to recent double wins by other authors.

A celebrity, referred to as PJS, is fighting to maintain a ban on his identity being revealed in the media regarding allegations of extramarital activities. The Supreme Court will hear arguments to determine if an appeal should be granted. The Court of Appeal previously ruled that PJS could not obtain a permanent injunction as details of the allegations had spread widely, making confidentiality difficult to maintain. The Sun on Sunday aims to publish a story about PJS's encounters with another individual, referred to as AB, and a subsequent three-way sexual encounter involving AB's partner, CD. PJS argues for his right to privacy, while News Group Newspapers, the publisher, contends that the story has already been published in other jurisdictions and circulated online.

Fosse Park, a retail park acquired for ÃÂ£345.5 million, is undergoing plans for improvement. The new owners aim to enhance parking, reduce traffic congestion, and revitalise the site's appearance. The leader of Blaby District Council, Ernie White, confirmed discussions with the new owners regarding planning matters. The park is considered a gateway to the city, and the goal is to create a more appealing entrance, addressing the current issue of unattractive shed backsides. The director of investments at Crown Estates, Paul Clarke, emphasised the focus on improving parking, reducing congestion, and upgrading the quality of common areas and facilities.

The live-action remake of "Beauty and the Beast" has sparked a debate in Malaysia due to a "gay moment" in the film. Despite the country's laws against homosexual activity, the Malaysian Censorship Board approved the movie with minor edits. The film's release was delayed for review, and the decision has received criticism online. The scene in question involves a side character, LeFou, grappling with his feelings for the antagonist Gaston. The delay has prompted refunds for advance ticket purchases, and a new release date is pending.

Landlords in Southampton are required to obtain a licence for Houses of Multiple Occupation (HMO) with more than three unrelated tenants, but many avoid it due to the high cost. This has led to an estimated 1,500 unlicensed HMOs in the city. Tenants often face eviction fears and poor living conditions. Nationally, mandatory HMO licensing targets larger properties with five or more unrelated occupants. Southampton's licensing scheme covers specific areas, and while most landlords comply, some resist, resulting in prosecutions.

The leaders of Fine Gael and Fianna FÃ¡il are trying to prevent a second election after the recent election failed to produce a majority government. Water charges are a contentious issue, with Fianna FÃ¡il advocating for their removal and Fine Gael supporting them. The election results gave Fine Gael 50 seats, Fianna FÃ¡il 44, Sinn FÃ©in 23, and Labour seven, but no party has been able to form a government, and a Taoiseach has yet to be elected.

The Sorrento ferry caught fire while sailing to Valencia, leading to a full evacuation of passengers and crew. At least three people were injured and hospitalized. The cause of the fire is unknown, but the ship may sink due to the damage. Passengers were rescued by nearby ships and are receiving support upon their return to Palma de Mallorca.

The Electoral Commission reported that 38 MPs raised concerns about potential double voting, a criminal offence, including students voting twice. The issue highlights the need for better integration of individual electoral registers to identify duplicates. Despite a record 46.8 million registered voters for the June 8th election, with a 68.7% turnout, concerns persist over duplicate applications, an issue from the EU referendum. The lack of direct links between electoral registers and the online registration service, using different databases, makes it challenging to identify duplicates, with an estimated 30-70% of applications being duplicates. This burdens electoral officials, and the Commission recommends clearer information and a verification function. While voting twice is a serious offence, Labour's Cat Smith cautions against measures that could hinder young and student registration, suggesting a nuanced approach to address double voting without deterring registration.

Lawrence Phillips, a former NFL player, is believed to have committed suicide while in prison. Phillips, a star player in the 1990s, had a promising career but was troubled by legal issues and anger problems. He was convicted of assault on multiple occasions and was serving a long prison sentence when he was accused of killing his cellmate. A judge recently ruled that Phillips would stand trial for this murder, and shortly after, he was found dead in his cell.

A Swaledale ram named Private Derby XXX was promoted to lance corporal in recognition of his good behaviour. This ram is the 30th in a line of mascot rams for the Mercian Regiment, dating back to the 19th century. He joined the regiment in 2014 and has participated in various public events, including meeting Prince William.

Liverpool's dramatic 4-3 victory over Borussia Dortmund in the Europa League quarterfinals was a thrilling encounter, with emotions running high and the game's outcome in doubt until the very end. The match showcased Liverpool's resilience and belief, inspired by manager Jurgen Klopp, as they came back from a 2-0 deficit to win with a late goal from Dejan Lovren. The victory brought back memories of Liverpool's famous Champions League comeback in 2005 and has given the team and fans renewed confidence. Klopp's impact on the club was evident, with his philosophy of never giving up and his ability to turn doubters into believers. The game also highlighted Liverpool's attacking prowess but also defensive vulnerabilities, which Klopp will likely address in the summer.

The EU Negotiation Joint Ministerial Committee met in London to discuss Brexit negotiations. UK government representative, Mr Davis, assured that Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland would be kept informed. However, Mr Russell from the Scottish government emphasized the need for transparency regarding the UK's plans, especially regarding EU market access and membership in the single market, which is crucial for Scotland's economy. Mr Davis proposed monthly meetings for information exchange and acknowledged the importance of considering different viewpoints. The Scottish government intends to oppose the UK government's appeal of the High Court judgment on Article 50 in the Supreme Court, with Lord Advocate James Wolffe representing Scotland's interests.

A flock of 13 cloned sheep, including four clones from the same adult ewe as Dolly (the first cloned mammal), are undergoing thorough physical examinations by veterinary surgeon Dr. Sandra Corr. These sheep are part of a study led by Professor Kevin Sinclair to investigate if cloned animals age normally and if they are as healthy as non-cloned animals. The study aims to address concerns about the cloning process potentially transferring "age-memory" and causing premature aging. The original Dolly died at six-and-a-half years old due to a virus and had osteoarthritis, raising questions about cloning's impact on health. To find answers, the cloned sheep, now approaching their ninth and tenth birthdays, have been monitored closely and subjected to various tests, including joint X-rays and full-body fMRI scans, focusing on age-related diseases. The study's results, with potential implications for cloning's future, will be published soon.

John Gosden's Shutter Speed won the Musidora Stakes, remaining unbeaten and securing a spot in the French Oaks at Chantilly. The soft ground was challenging, but she displayed class and will be better suited to firmer conditions.
