Paul Merson, a Sky Sports pundit, criticised Andros Townsend's inclusion in the England squad, questioning his ability. Townsend, a Tottenham midfielder, responded by scoring a crucial goal for England against Italy, proving Merson wrong. Merson acknowledged his mistake but later reignited the debate by tweeting about Townsend's brief appearance in Tottenham's match against Burnley.

Chelsea have made an offer to sign 22-year-old Japanese forward Yoshinori Muto from FC Tokyo. If the transfer goes through, Muto will initially join Chelsea's partner club, Vitesse Arnhem, on loan. The player has expressed his honour at receiving the offer but is yet to make a decision. Muto, a recent economics graduate, would be the first Japanese player to represent Chelsea if he chooses to move. The transfer fee is rumoured to be around Â£4 million.

A large-scale study has discovered that babies who receive antibiotics during the first six months of life are more likely to become overweight as toddlers. The research, published in Pediatrics, suggests a potential link between antibiotic use and weight gain, similar to the effect observed in farm animals. The study analyzed data from over 12,000 healthy two-year-olds and their antibiotic prescription records, finding that boys were more susceptible to weight gain after antibiotic use. While the study does not establish causation, it raises concerns about the potential contribution of antibiotics to the childhood obesity epidemic and emphasizes the need for cautious antibiotic use in infants.

A member of the Queen's Guard at Buckingham Palace experienced an embarrassing moment during the Changing of the Guard ceremony. He slipped on a manhole cover, falling sideways and dropping his rifle. The incident was captured on camera by a tourist, David Meadwell, who was visiting London with his family. The guard quickly recovered and continued the ceremony, but not before realizing the large crowd witnessing his mishap. The fall was likely caused by the metal protectors on his boot soles. Despite the incident, the Ministry of Defence declined to comment, emphasizing that the guard was simply performing his duties.

The iconic TV miniseries "Roots," which captivated over 100 million viewers in 1977, is being remade by A&E networks for a 2016 release. The new version will be simulcast on A&E, Lifetime, and History, and will closely follow Alex Haley's novel, with added input from African and African-American history scholars. The remake aims to introduce the powerful story of Kunta Kinte, an African slave, to a new generation, while also appealing to fans of the original. LeVar Burton, the original Kinte, will co-executive produce, emphasizing the enduring relevance of the story in light of recent racial milestones and tensions in the U.S.

A former royal footman, Christopher Lawler, has accused palace aides at Clarence House of attempting to force him into an orgy in 1978. Lawler, now 64, claims he was groped and pinned to a chair by staff members on his first day of work, leaving him traumatised. He reported the incident to palace officials last year, prompted by investigations into historical child sex abuse cases. Despite initial rejections, the complaint was eventually passed to Scotland Yard. A retired royal aide was interviewed but denied involvement. The Palace has assured Lawler of their cooperation with police inquiries.

An Oregon couple, Jesse and Melissa Meek, creatively announced their pregnancy through a rap video set to the theme of the '90s sitcom 'The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air'. The video, which has gone viral with over 1.7 million views on YouTube, showcases the couple rapping about their journey to parenthood. They reveal that they are expecting a child and share a sonogram at the end. The Meeks' video is a playful take on the original song, replacing the story of Will Smith's character with their own experience of trying to conceive. The couple was surprised by the video's unexpected success, and they plan to potentially create another video after finding out the gender of their baby.

A dress worn by Vivien Leigh in the iconic 1939 film Gone With the Wind sold for $137,000 at auction. The outfit, consisting of a jacket and full skirt, was featured in several significant scenes. The auction also included over 150 other items from the film, such as a straw hat worn by Leigh and clothing items from Clark Gable's character's wardrobe. The dress was part of James Tumblin's extensive collection of Hollywood memorabilia, which he started in the 1960s. Tumblin acquired the dress for $20, saving it from being discarded. Gone With the Wind, celebrated for its 75th anniversary, was adapted from Margaret Mitchell's book and featured Hattie McDaniel, who made history as the first African-American actor to win an Academy Award.

A two-year-old boy fell into a cheetah exhibit at the Cleveland Metroparks Zoo after his parents allegedly dangled him over the edge. The child slipped from his mother's arms, falling 10 to 12 feet into the pit. The boy was quickly rescued by his parents and sustained minor injuries. Zoo officials and eyewitnesses reported that the cheetahs did not approach the child, possibly due to the commotion. The zoo plans to file child endangerment charges against the family, and the exhibit has been temporarily closed.

A speed camera, previously used to enforce a 30mph limit in Birmingham, has been re-angled to point directly at a house in the West Midlands. The camera, along with around 300 others, was switched off in 2013 due to obsolete technology. It is a mystery who re-angled the camera, but Birmingham City Council is aware and will send an engineer to potentially remove it. The camera will not be included in a new pilot scheme for digital technology cameras.

Usain Bolt, the six-time Olympic gold medallist, will represent Jamaica at the IAAF/BTC World Relays in the Bahamas on May 2nd and 3rd. Bolt expressed his excitement, noting Jamaica's strong relay tradition and his commitment to representing his country proudly. The Jamaican team list for the event will be revealed soon.

Neymar and Dani Alves, along with Neymar's sister Rafaella, showed their support for FC Barcelona by attending a basketball game between Barcelona and Real Madrid, known as El Clasico. Barcelona won the Euro League contest 85-80. The passage also mentions Neymar's involvement in a football match where Brazil beat Chile 1-0, and an upcoming La Liga match against Celta Vigo as Barcelona pursues a treble of trophies.

Italy is experiencing a surge in migrants from Africa and the Middle East, with over 8,480 rescued in just four days. The Italian Coast Guard has been active in rescue operations, responding to numerous distress calls. There are concerns about a potential tragedy, with reports of a missing boat carrying 550 people, although the Coast Guard has not confirmed this incident. The International Organization for Migration (IOM) reports that Italy has seen over 10,000 migrant arrivals in 2015, with many originating from West Africa, Somalia, and Syria, and using Libya as a transit point. The dangerous journey has led to the deaths of at least 480 migrants due to factors like bad weather and overcrowded boats.

Alexis Sanchez, a highly sought-after forward, chose to join Arsenal and their manager Arsene Wenger over Liverpool, despite the latter's interest. Sanchez has been a success at Arsenal, scoring 19 goals and impressing with his all-round game. Wenger is pleased with Sanchez's decision and attributes it to the player's belief in his management. The Arsenal boss also praises Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers for his team's performance, despite recent setbacks.

Sir Bradley Wiggins, a renowned British cyclist with an impressive Olympic and Tour de France record, will attempt to break the cycling hour record on June 7 at the London Olympic Velodrome. The hour record, a prestigious feat in cycling, has recently regained popularity due to reformed regulations. Wiggins, motivated by the challenge, aims to inspire others to take up cycling. He will compete against the current record set by Australian Rohan Dennis, who cycled 52.491km in an hour. The event is expected to attract a large crowd and will be broadcast live, with tickets on sale from April 19.

Serena Williams, a two-time French Open champion, admitted that her challenging victory over Sara Errani in the Fed Cup exposed her lack of preparation for the claycourt season. Despite winning, Williams was not satisfied with her performance, acknowledging the need to adjust her game from hard courts to clay. The match, played in tough weather conditions, highlighted Williams' dominance and her quest to win all majors this year. However, her doubles loss with Alison Riske resulted in the US's relegation to World Group II. The US captain, Mary Joe Fernandez, emphasised the need for harder work and expressed optimism about the team's future with many players in the top 100 rankings.

River Plate, an Argentine football club, are interested in re-signing their former player, Radamel Falcao, who is currently on loan at Manchester United from Monaco. Falcao, a 29-year-old Colombian striker, has struggled at United, scoring only four Premier League goals this season. However, he has recently been in good form for his national team, equalling Colombia's all-time goalscoring record. River Plate's vice president, Matias Patanian, expressed their desire to bring Falcao back, stating that the club dreams of his return. Falcao previously played for River Plate for eight years, joining at age 15 and scoring 34 goals in 90 appearances during his time with the first team.

Ella Henderson, known for her powerful vocals and appearance on The X Factor, has been announced as the face of dry shampoo brand Batiste's 2015 'Ready For It' campaign. The campaign features Henderson showcasing various hairstyles against vibrant city backdrops. This collaboration marks Henderson's first brand partnership and Batiste's international campaign launch, featuring her single 'Mirror Man'.

A billboard featuring Officer Pablo Torres, who shot and killed Aaron Siler, has caused outrage among Siler's family and friends. The billboard, funded by the Kenosha Professional Police Association, was intended to thank the community for their support, but Siler's loved ones find it disrespectful and hurtful. The incident has sparked controversy, with the police association claiming no offence was intended, while Siler's family demands the billboard's removal. The investigation into Siler's death is ongoing, adding to the tension surrounding the case.

Eight Iranian border guards were killed in a clash with militants near the Pakistan border. The militants, belonging to the group Jaish al Adal, crossed into Iran from Pakistan and were responsible for previous attacks on Iranian territory. Iranian officials have requested Pakistan's assistance in capturing the surviving assailants, accusing Pakistan of not controlling terrorist activities. Pakistan has condemned the attack and promised to investigate and apprehend the militants if they are found within their borders.

The Japanese Defense Minister, Gen Nakatani, assured the public that the Air Self Defense Force (ASDF) has never encountered extraterrestrial UFOs. This statement was in response to a question from lawmaker Antonio Inoki, a former wrestler known for his diverse career. Inoki had inquired about potential extraterrestrial threats and alien research. The discussion highlights Japan's engagement with unconventional topics, as politicians have previously debated the legal consequences of defending against an alien invasion.

A 35-year-old passenger, Jin Pai, was hospitalised with deep cuts on his leg and buttocks after a toilet he was squatting on broke and shattered. The incident occurred at Hefei Xinqiao International Airport in Hefei, China, when Jin Pai stood on the toilet rim due to cleanliness concerns. The broken porcelain caused multiple cuts, and he was found bleeding on the floor after calling his companions for help. Jin Pai initially admitted to squatting but later changed his story to the police, claiming he was sitting when the toilet collapsed. Authorities considered it an accident and reminded people to use toilets appropriately.

Kevin Rebbie, a 56-year-old man from Limerick Township, Pennsylvania, was arrested for sexually abusing a 15-year-old girl over four years and filming her and others with a hidden camera in the bathroom. The investigation started when the victim discovered the camera and reported it to the police. Rebbie faces multiple charges, including aggravated indecent assault and sexual abuse of children. He admitted to filming several victims, specifically targeting the 15-year-old. The police chief emphasized the severity of the crime, and Rebbie's bail is set at $500,000.

Japanese photographer YÃ»ki Aoyama has created a unique series of father-daughter portraits, showcasing a playful contrast. In these images, daughters pose with a straight face while their fathers leap energetically, dressed in suits. The project, titled "Daughter and Salary Man," offers a light-hearted take on traditional family portraits, allowing fathers to express their fun side. The photographs have gained online attention for their creative approach, featuring various poses and emotions, all set against Japanese landmarks.

Kevin Pietersen, the 34-year-old batsman, is making a potential return to the England cricket team after being controversially dismissed by the former managing director, Paul Downton, in 2014. Pietersen's last international appearance was during the disastrous Ashes tour in Australia last year, where England suffered a whitewash defeat. With the start of the county championship season approaching, Pietersen rejoined Surrey, aiming to regain his place in the England Test team. The dismissal of Downton has opened up this opportunity, and Pietersen's presence at the Surrey team photo shoot at the KIA Oval has sparked discussions about his possible comeback.

Ceahlaul Piatra Neamt, a Romanian club facing relegation, has dismissed their Brazilian coach Ze Maria, a former Brazil international, for the second time in a week. His initial sacking followed a poor run of form, but he was quickly reinstated. However, after a subsequent defeat, the club's owner decided to terminate his contract again. Ze Maria will be succeeded by Serbian coach Vanya Radinovic.

Radamel Falcao's former Monaco teammate Nabil Dirar believes Falcao regrets his loan move to Manchester United, despite his unhappiness in France. Falcao's struggles at United, coupled with a previous knee injury, have led to a poor season, scoring only four goals. United are unlikely to make the transfer permanent due to his underperformance. Dirar suggests Falcao would have been better off staying at Monaco, where he could have played in the Champions League, but acknowledges Falcao's need for a more vibrant atmosphere.

A man wearing a distinctive cartoon mask and a fluoro orange sweatshirt robbed a Christchurch dairy, taking the till and approximately $1500 in cash. The offender, described as very tall, was captured on security footage. Police are appealing to the public for help in identifying the man, who remains at large.

Kaitlyn Granado, a 24-year-old math teacher at MacArthur High School in Irving, Texas, has been arrested twice for inappropriate relationships with underage students. The first arrest occurred in March when she admitted to kissing and allowing a 15-year-old pupil to touch her breasts. The second arrest followed allegations from another 15-year-old pupil, claiming they had sex on consecutive nights in January in her car. Granado was released on bail, and the school district placed her on administrative leave, ensuring she has no contact with students.

A video of a crocodile with a dead dog in its jaws has gone viral, shocking viewers. The incident occurred in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, where a tourist witnessed the crocodile attack and capture a local dog. The crocodile was seen calmly swimming in the marina, holding its catch for hours. The dog's owner was identified as the local bike shop owner. This event has sparked reactions of horror on social media, highlighting the close proximity of crocodiles to humans in the area due to urbanization.

Steve Bruce expresses confidence in Hull City's ability to avoid relegation from the Premier League, despite a recent 2-0 loss to Southampton. Bruce initially aimed for 10 wins to ensure survival, but now believes fewer wins might be sufficient. Hull faces a challenging run of fixtures against top teams, but Bruce remains optimistic, citing their recent successes. He attributes their struggles to long-term injuries of key players and believes they can still turn their season around. Southampton's victory moved them up to fifth in the table, but manager Ronald Koeman faced an issue with Sadio Mane attempting to take a penalty against team rules.

A teacher, Ian Guffick, was banned from teaching for at least two years after he allowed and made changes to his students' SATs exam answers, invalidating the entire school's results. Guffick admitted to altering some answers himself and asking pupils to modify their responses, despite the exam session being over. The Department for Education annulled the school's results after an investigation by the local education authority. Guffick resigned from his position and acknowledged his actions as unacceptable professional conduct. The panel found his behaviour dishonest but not fraudulent, considering his regret and cooperation during the investigation.

Anders Lindegaard, a Danish footballer, married Swedish model Misse Beqiri in a beach wedding in Mauritius last year. Despite limited playing time at Manchester United, Lindegaard shared a photo with his wife on Instagram, enjoying the English weather. The couple has a son and has been together since 2012. Beqiri, of Albanian descent, is an active Instagram user with over 17,000 followers, often sharing modelling photos. Lindegaard's football career has been challenging, with only 19 league appearances in five seasons, and he is currently third-choice goalkeeper at United.

The iconic blue letters that once adorned Yankee Stadium in the Bronx failed to sell at a Sotheby's auction, despite expectations of a high price. Owned by baseball legend Reggie Jackson, the 13 letters, each 10 feet tall, were estimated to fetch between $300,000 and $600,000. However, the auction saw no bids, except for a Sotheby's employee's attempt to initiate bidding. Jackson, who bought the letters after the stadium's final game in 2008, expressed his desire for a new generation to cherish this New York City symbol. The letters, installed in 1976, hold historical significance for the Yankees and the city. Interestingly, a New York Mets bullpen car from the 1960s exceeded its estimated value, selling for $112,500.

Brendan Rodgers, Liverpool manager, addressed Raheem Sterling and Jordon Ibe's recent controversial actions, emphasizing their professional obligations. Despite the incidents, neither player faced discipline. Rodgers highlighted the challenges young athletes face in managing public perception, urging them to learn from these experiences. He also discussed the team's progress and the importance of learning from past losses, referencing Steven Gerrard's availability for the upcoming FA Cup semi-final.

Mesut Ozil, the Arsenal playmaker, shared a glimpse of his downtime at home with his dog after a successful international break with Germany. Ozil, who missed Arsenal's previous game due to illness, is expected to start against Liverpool. He has been in excellent form since returning from injury, contributing goals and assists. Ozil also expressed his comfort with the demanding English football schedule, stating that he fits in 'perfectly' due to his preference for playing in many matches.

Josep Maria Bartomeu, president of Barcelona, has confirmed that the club is not looking to replace manager Luis Enrique, who has impressed since taking charge last summer. Despite speculation, Bartomeu expressed satisfaction with Enrique's performance, highlighting his focus and preparation. Enrique's side recently defeated Valencia, with goals from Luis Suarez and Lionel Messi, and are in a strong position to win multiple trophies this season.

Jordan Henderson, Liverpool's vice-captain, has agreed to a new long-term contract with the club, worth approximately Â£100,000 per week, until the summer of 2020. This news comes after impressive performances and 13 assists from Henderson this season, making him a key player under manager Brendan Rodgers. With Steven Gerrard's impending departure, Henderson is a potential candidate for the club's captaincy.

Filipe Luis, the Brazilian left-back, is determined to see out his three-year contract at Chelsea, despite Atletico Madrid's interest in re-signing him. Luis, who has faced competition for his position, expressed his happiness at Chelsea and his commitment to helping the team win the Premier League title. Jose Mourinho, Chelsea's manager, demands focus and concentration from his players as they face a challenging run of games.

Nathan Hughes, a rugby player for Wasps, had his three-match ban overturned on appeal after accidentally knocking out George North during a game. The original ban was criticised by many, including fellow players and club members, who argued there was no intent. The appeal panel reviewed new evidence and ruled that the incident was accidental, allowing Hughes to return to play immediately.

A stunning sunset with deep red hues captivated Seattle residents, as captured by photographer Tim Durkan. The phenomenon was caused by wildfires in Siberia, where farmers' grass-burning activities escalated due to strong winds. The fires' smoke travelled across the Pacific, affecting the Pacific Northwest's air quality. The red colour resulted from smoke particles filtering out shorter wavelength colours, allowing red and orange hues to dominate during sunrise and sunset.

Becky Schoenig's new car was stolen from her driveway in St. Louis, Missouri. It was later found and returned to her with new red rims and detailing, as well as a strong smell of cigarettes and marijuana. Instead of being upset, Schoenig took to Facebook to express her amusement, thanking the thieves for "pimping out" her car. She also created a smoothie at her restaurant, The Hot Pot, named after the man who helped locate her car, Mick Sexton.

Manchester City players face a significant financial loss of Â£500,000 each in bonuses if they fail to secure a Champions League spot for the upcoming season. This is part of the club's strategy to comply with financial fair play regulations, offering incentivised contracts to star players. Currently in fourth place, a recent defeat to rivals Manchester United has left their European hopes uncertain. The team's inconsistent form, with seven losses since the start of 2015, including early exits from the FA Cup and Champions League, has led to a tight race for Champions League qualification. With the top three teams automatically qualifying, City must finish in the top four to secure their place, or risk a substantial financial impact on the players' earnings.

Manchester United's Under 18s defeated Manchester City 1-0 in a match featuring many local players. The game, played at Altrincham's stadium, was a contrast to the senior teams' upcoming derby, with free entry and a different atmosphere. Callum Gribbin's free-kick secured the win for United, showcasing his skill. The match highlighted the potential of young players, with both teams displaying talent and commitment.

Joe Hart, the England and Manchester City goalkeeper, praised his Italian counterpart Gianluigi Buffon, calling him a 'legend of the game' after Buffon earned his 147th cap in the 1-1 draw between England and Italy. Hart, who reached his own milestone of 50 caps, expressed his admiration for Buffon's longevity and achievements, considering him an inspiration as he continues to develop his own career. Hart also shared his ambition to keep playing for both club and country and accumulate more international appearances.

Chipotle, a popular Mexican restaurant chain, is entering the food delivery market by partnering with the Postmates app to offer delivery services in 67 cities. This move comes as Chipotle aims to capitalise on the growing demand for food delivery, estimated to be a $70 billion market. Customers will incur a 9% service charge on top of delivery fees starting at $5, which vary based on distance and demand. The partnership with Postmates, which utilises independent contractors similar to Uber, marks a shift for Chipotle, as they had previously declined similar offers from other delivery services. The restaurant's popularity is evident, with presidential candidates Marco Rubio and Hillary Clinton being spotted at Chipotle outlets. Other major food chains like Starbucks, Taco Bell, McDonald's, and Burger King are also exploring or implementing delivery services to tap into this lucrative market.

The parents of Martin Richard, the youngest victim of the Boston Marathon bombings, have written an opinion piece in The Boston Globe, pleading for the death penalty to be removed as an option for the convicted bomber, Dzhokhar Tsarnaev. The parents, Bill and Denise Richard, explain that while they understand the severity of the crimes, they wish to avoid years of appeals and reliving the traumatic event. They propose a life sentence without the possibility of release or appeal for Tsarnaev, hoping to bring closure to the case and move forward from the tragedy.

A Boeing 747 has been transformed into a luxurious private residence for a billionaire, costing an estimated Â£400 million. This custom-built jet, typically accommodating 600 passengers, has been tailored to the owner's specifications, featuring bedrooms, multiple lounges, a dining room, a kitchen, and an onboard restaurant. The plane's interior resembles a high-end hotel, offering a unique and exclusive flying experience far beyond commercial first-class standards.

SpaceX launched a Falcon 9 rocket and Dragon cargo spacecraft towards the International Space Station, but failed to land the rocket stage on a floating barge. Despite the setback, SpaceX aims to reduce space access costs by reusing rockets. The Dragon will deliver supplies, including an espresso maker, and later return with science experiments and waste. This is SpaceX's sixth mission to the ISS, with the first launch attempt scrubbed due to weather.

Priscilla Presley is set to witness the first wedding at a new Las Vegas chapel dedicated to Elvis Presley. The wedding is part of a contest organised with NBC's Today show, offering an Elvis-themed wedding package to one lucky couple. The wedding will take place at the Westgate Hotel, where Elvis performed numerous sold-out shows. The winning couple will receive a free wedding reception, hotel stay, airfares, and concert tickets. Priscilla emphasised the chapel's high-quality experience, with no Elvis impersonators. Couples must submit entries to win the contest, explaining why they deserve the Elvis-themed wedding.

Liverpool's Jordan Henderson believes his team can challenge Manchester City for the Premier League title, despite a demanding season. Henderson and Liverpool are four points behind City, who have faltered recently, and with a crucial win over Newcastle United, Henderson feels they can apply pressure in the race for the Champions League. Raheem Sterling and Joe Allen scored in the 2-0 victory, with Allen's goal securing a vital win in the league battle.

Roma secured a crucial home win against Napoli in Serie A, ending their four-month winless streak at home. Miralem Pjanic's 25th-minute goal, assisted by Juan Iturbe and Alessandro Florenzi, sealed the victory. The win moved Roma four points ahead of Lazio in the race for Champions League spots. Napoli, on the other hand, extended their winless streak to five games, staying in fifth place. The match was significant due to heightened security measures, with fans from the Campania region barred from attending and a large police presence due to past tensions between the clubs.

Doncaster Rovers and Fleetwood Town played a dull 0-0 draw in League One, offering little excitement for fans. The match highlights video was comically short, lasting only 27 seconds, reflecting the lack of noteworthy action.

A man, Roland Giroux, has developed a unique bond with his pet fish, a blood parrot cichlid. Despite the challenge of interacting with a marine pet, Giroux has trained his fish to enjoy physical touch. The fish responds positively to Giroux's massages, even seeking out his hand for more. Giroux's dedication to the fish's socialisation is evident, as he spends at least 15 minutes daily massaging and playing with it. The fish's behaviour suggests it has become accustomed to and enjoys human interaction, forming an unusual but remarkable connection with its owner.

Ben Stokes, a fiery character in the England cricket team, has a reputation for aggression, which he has learned to channel positively. After a year of ups and downs, he is back in the team, and his natural exuberance and willingness to take on opponents are valued. England's coach, Peter Moores, has provided guidance on managing Stokes' temperament, ensuring his aggression is controlled and beneficial to the team's performance. Stokes' ability to contribute runs and wickets while maintaining his character is crucial, and the team aims to strike a balance between harnessing his talent and occasionally reining him in.

Wales' crucial Euro 2016 qualifier against Belgium, scheduled for June 12 at the Cardiff City Stadium, has sold out with 33,000 tickets. Both teams are at the top of Group B with 11 points, but Belgium leads due to a better goal difference. Wales' recent 3-0 win over Israel has raised hopes for qualification, as they aim for a spot in the 2016 finals in France. The match was originally intended for the larger Millennium Stadium, but UEFA rules prohibit venue changes within 120 days of the game. The Wales squad prefers the more intimate atmosphere of the Cardiff City Stadium.

England's Under-17 football team, the defending champions, will compete in the upcoming UEFA European Championship in Bulgaria. Coach John Peacock has announced the squad, featuring talented players from various Premier League clubs. The team has a strong record, having qualified with a 100% win rate. They are placed in Group D with Holland, Italy, and the Republic of Ireland, and will begin their defence against Italy on May 7th. The squad includes Chelsea's Jay Dasilva and Ike Ugbo, Arsenal's Chris Willock and Stephy Mavididi, and a recalled Liverpool duo, Herbie Kane and Trent Arnold.

Manchester City are interested in signing the highly-rated 14-year-old Anderlecht playmaker, Evangelos Patoulidis. The Belgian teenager has garnered attention from top European clubs like Arsenal and Barcelona due to his impressive talent. Despite previously rejecting Barcelona's La Masia academy, Manchester City's manager, Manuel Pellegrini, aims to secure Patoulidis' services as a long-term investment.

A 23-year-old man was arrested in connection with the death of Vanessa Santillan, a 33-year-old transgender escort, who was found strangled and beaten in a flat in Fulham, London, in late March. The man has been bailed but is expected to return for further questioning. Police are appealing for information from anyone who had contact with Miss Santillan in the hours before her death. Detective Chief Inspector Rebecca Reeves is leading the investigation and is seeking to understand the motive behind the killing.

A woman named Dawn, who experienced seven miscarriages, was devastated to find out that her friend and housemate, Jamie, stole Â£207 intended for her baby's gravestone. The theft was revealed on The Jeremy Kyle Show through a lie detector test. Jamie, a convicted burglar, initially denied the accusation but later confessed in a Facebook message, blaming his girlfriend Carol. Dawn, feeling betrayed, expressed her grief and anger over the loss of the money meant to honour her child.

ISIS has released over 200 Yazidis, primarily women and children, with the help of Arab tribal leaders. The Yazidis, a persecuted Kurdish minority, were targeted by ISIS last summer, leading to killings, captivity, and displacement. The release's motivation is unclear, but previous releases have occurred. The Yazidis' plight sparked a humanitarian crisis and international response, including airstrikes against ISIS.

Harry Kane, the Tottenham and England striker, is celebrated in a new animation showcasing his standout season. The video, titled 'Harry Kane - PFA Player of the Year?', features his goals and celebrations, using a unique animation technique with still photographs. Kane's remarkable season has led to nominations for both the PFA Player and Young Player of the Year awards, competing against top players like Eden Hazard and Alexis Sanchez.

Jamie Carragher, a former Liverpool defender, expresses his support for Brendan Rodgers as the manager of Liverpool despite the team's recent struggles. Carragher believes that Rodgers should not be judged solely on the lack of trophies this season and has faith in the manager's ability to improve the team for the next season. He acknowledges the challenges of integrating new players and suggests that the right signings in the upcoming transfer window will be crucial for Liverpool's success. Carragher also highlights his own community work on Merseyside, where he provides coaching in deprived areas, and shares his motivation to give back to his hometown.

A four-year-old boy, James Hayward, had his plastic toy gun confiscated at East Midlands Airport by security staff who deemed it a security risk. The incident sparked debate as the boy's father, Phil Hayward, criticised the 'over-zealous' security checks, arguing that it was unnecessary to take a harmless toy from a child. The airport defended their decision, stating that they follow government regulations which prohibit any items resembling a prohibited item, including replica or model guns. The family received an apology and an offer to return the toy, but ultimately, the boy was bought a replacement.

A 31-year-old man named Rich from Humpty Doo, Northern Territory, posted an online advertisement on Gumtree seeking a girlfriend or wife. He listed his requirements for an ideal partner, including preferences for a non-drinker, non-smoker, someone fit and attractive, and someone who enjoys the outdoors but can also be a princess. Rich described himself as athletic, tattooed, and with a successful career, and he offered various perks to the successful candidate, such as a company car, phone, and laptop. He emphasized his willingness to spend money on his partner and encouraged interested women to apply.

Football Association chairman Greg Dyke aims to implement significant changes to boost the presence of homegrown players in English football. He proposes increasing the minimum number of homegrown players in club squads and redefining the criteria for 'home-grown' status. Five former England managers have expressed their support for Dyke's proposals, warning that blocking these changes could hinder England's footballing success. The managers highlight the shrinking pool of English talent at the top level and advocate for more opportunities for young English players, citing the success of emerging stars like Harry Kane.

Demelza Poldark, a character in the show, has given birth to a baby girl, surprising fans as her pregnancy was only recently announced. The quick progression of her pregnancy, from announcement to birth within minutes, has been noted by viewers, who also observed a similar rapid timeline in a previous character's pregnancy. Despite the show's heartthrob, Ross Poldark, being married to Demelza, women across the country have expressed their desire to be with him.

Nigel Pearson, Leicester's manager, has asked his team to stay calm and concentrate on their own performance, rather than their relegation rivals, as they fight to stay in the Premier League. Despite recent wins, including a last-minute victory over West Bromwich Albion, Leicester are still bottom of the table and only three points from safety. Pearson wants his players to focus on their own games, rather than other teams' results, to ensure their survival.

A North Pacific gray whale named Varvara has set a new record for the longest mammal migration, swimming approximately 14,000 miles. This journey challenges previous assumptions about the whale's origins and species classification, suggesting that some western gray whales might actually be eastern grays. The whale's remarkable navigation abilities over vast distances have intrigued scientists, potentially impacting the understanding of whale genetics and population numbers.

A large section of the seabed, approximately 1,000ft long, suddenly emerged along the coast of Hokkaido Island, Japan, surprising residents. The new landmass, rising up to 50ft above sea level, is believed to be the result of a landslide caused by melting ice and snow. Geologists and researchers conducted aerial surveys to study the phenomenon, which revealed no prior indications of land movement. The event is not considered related to recent earthquakes in the region.

Gregory van der Wiel, the Dutch defender, has refuted rumours of his departure from Paris Saint-Germain, expressing his love for the club, city, and teammates. Despite a recent dispute with manager Laurent Blanc, which led to his exclusion from a Champions League match, van der Wiel maintains his happiness at PSG and desires a contract renewal. However, with ongoing speculation linking PSG to Barcelona's Dani Alves, van der Wiel's future at the club may be uncertain.

Carlos Tevez, the former Manchester City striker, is in talks to terminate his contract with Juventus and rejoin his former club, Boca Juniors in Argentina. Despite being on course for a successful season with Juventus, Tevez has expressed his desire to leave, and the club has acknowledged his wishes. Boca Juniors' president confirmed they are close to finalising the deal but emphasised that Tevez must first end his contract with Juventus, which runs until 2016. Tevez's potential move is not expected to impact his international career, as his manager supports the decision, stating that both Juventus and Boca Juniors are excellent teams.

Bayern Munich's manager, Pep Guardiola, accidentally tore his trousers during the Champions League match against Porto, exposing his underwear. The incident occurred during a thrilling game where Bayern dominated, leading 5-0 at half-time and eventually winning 6-1. This victory secured their spot in the semi-finals, showcasing their superiority over a stunned Porto side. Guardiola's wardrobe malfunction added a light-hearted moment to the evening, with the manager humorously acknowledging the need for new trousers.

A multi-vehicle crash in Brisbane's west involved ten people, including four children. The collision of three vehicles on the Brisbane Valley Highway near Fernvale resulted in various injuries. A man and a child were the first to be airlifted to a hospital in Brisbane, followed by a woman and another child. Six others were taken to Ipswich Hospital, and one person was freed from their vehicle by emergency services. The highway was temporarily closed, causing diversions.

Arsenal midfielder Mesut Ozil has acquired a new Apple Watch, which he proudly displayed on Instagram, comparing it to Michael Knight's watch from the show Knight Rider. With six games left in the Premier League season, Arsenal is preparing for a crucial match against league leaders Chelsea, trailing by 10 points. The team has been boosted by the return of Jack Wilshere, who former Arsenal player Ray Parlour believes has the potential to be a key player if he can maintain his fitness.

Mark Clattenburg, a leading Premier League referee, will officiate the Manchester derby between United and City, despite previous controversies and accusations of bias. Clattenburg has sent off three players from both clubs this season, including City's Vincent Kompany during an international match. The derby holds extra significance as United recently moved ahead of City in the league table, with City struggling for form.

Bob Katter, a federal MP of Lebanese descent, accused the Queensland Government of assuming Billy Gordon, an embattled MP, would resign due to accusations of domestic violence and a hidden criminal past. Katter's statement, which included a controversial reference to Gordon as a "little black puppet on a string," sparked criticism on social media for its terminology and Katter's speaking on Gordon's behalf. Katter defended his choice of words, relating it to his personal experiences and calling out what he saw as racial overtones in the government's treatment of Gordon.

Dayna Dobias, a 19-year-old from Illinois with cerebral palsy, is using her dancing videos to challenge stereotypes and inspire others. Despite facing bullying and judgment, Dayna aims to showcase that her disability does not define her abilities or her worth. Through her videos and motivational speaking, she wants to encourage people to look beyond disabilities and see the person.

Orlando City, an MLS team with a large Latin-American fan base, has shown interest in acquiring Javier Hernandez, a Manchester United player who has struggled during his loan at Real Madrid. Hernandez's potential arrival in Orlando would be well-received by the fans, but they face competition from eight European clubs also vying for his signature. Meanwhile, Manchester United has presented an improved contract offer to young talent Andreas Pereira, who is being courted by several European teams after declining United's initial proposal.

A group of three or more individuals committed arson by setting a car on fire at a South Los Angeles gas station early Saturday morning. The driver of the white Dodge Charger had an argument with the suspects, who then doused the car in gasoline and ignited it while two passengers were inside. Although the car was severely damaged, no one was injured. The incident is being investigated as arson, and surveillance footage is being used to identify the suspects.

Charles Manuel, a chiropractor from southern Iowa, has surrendered his state license after admitting to engaging in inappropriate and unethical practices. He was accused of accepting sex as payment for services and performing exorcisms on patients. Despite these serious allegations, Manuel received positive patient satisfaction evaluations on HealthGrades.com. As part of an agreement, Manuel has pledged not to apply for license reinstatement for at least 10 years and must prove that the circumstances surrounding the revocation no longer exist.

A Russian fighter jet's interception of a U.S. reconnaissance plane over the Baltic Sea has prompted the United States to lodge a complaint with Moscow. The U.S. claims the Russian pilot acted unsafely and unprofessionally, while Russia alleges the U.S. plane had its transponder switched off, a claim denied by the U.S. This incident follows a similar encounter between a Russian jet and a U.S. RC-135U a year ago, highlighting the frequent interactions between Russian and U.S. aircraft in various regions.

An FBI agent's sniper rifle was stolen from his car in a Salt Lake City hotel parking lot, just before President Obama's visit to Utah. The rifle was securely locked, but the thief managed to break into the car and use force to remove the weapon. Other items, including a gear bag and clothing, were also taken. The theft occurred overnight at a hotel near the airport and the FBI office, which did not have surveillance cameras. The rifle's serial number has been recorded, and the Secret Service was informed, but the weapon has not been recovered.

Luigi Costa, 71, is on trial for the brutal murder of his neighbour Terrence Freebody in 2012. Costa allegedly stomped on Freebody's head, cut his throat, and stabbed him multiple times. Forensic psychiatrist Professor Paul Mullen believes Costa's mental state was compromised by dementia and alcohol abuse, leading to a confused and fluctuating mood during the incident. The defence argues that Costa's unstable mindset at the time of the attack could result in a not-guilty verdict.

Everton manager Roberto Martinez defended Ross Barkley's decision to take a penalty instead of Leighton Baines, who has a better success rate. Barkley missed, but Martinez argued that Barkley had the right to take it and showed responsibility. The miss didn't affect the outcome as Everton won 1-0, thanks to a goal from Kevin Mirallas.

Two passengers were found dead in a suspected murder-suicide on a Holland America cruise ship in Puerto Rico. The incident occurred on March 29 during a Southern Caribbean cruise that departed from Tampa, Florida. The bodies were discovered by cleaning staff, and the FBI is investigating the case.

Patrick Kluivert, a former Dutch forward and assistant coach, successfully led the Caribbean island team Curacao to advance to the second qualifying round of the 2018 World Cup in CONCACAF. Curacao drew 2-2 in the second leg against Montserrat, winning 4-3 on aggregate. Kluivert's team secured the victory with a late goal from Charlton Vicento, a former Holland U21 player. Curacao will now face Cuba in the next round. Kluivert has a personal connection to Curacao through his mother's heritage and has previous World Cup experience as a player and assistant coach.

Esteban Cambiasso, a veteran footballer with an impressive trophy haul, believes that helping Leicester City avoid relegation from the Premier League would be a significant achievement, akin to winning a cup or a league title. Despite Leicester's precarious position at the bottom of the table, Cambiasso remains optimistic about their survival chances, citing his belief in the team's abilities. He joined Leicester in the summer, leaving Inter Milan after a decade, and has become a key player, potentially extending his stay beyond his initial one-year contract due to his happiness at the club.

A young mother, Gemma, is at risk of being barred from seeing her two children due to her irresponsible behaviour, including excessive drinking, partying, and suspected theft. Gemma's mother, Debbie, has been raising the children since they were four months old and is now considering banning Gemma from her home, citing her daughter's lack of responsibility and concern for the children's well-being. Debbie believes Gemma prioritises her party lifestyle over motherhood and is concerned about her use of legal highs and past stealing.

In a Premier League match between Chelsea and Manchester United, Chelsea's Eden Hazard scored a goal, but the Sky Sports pundits unanimously agreed that the build-up involved a foul by Chelsea captain John Terry on Manchester United striker Radamel Falcao. Terry's strong challenge from behind caused Falcao to lose possession, leading to the scoring move. The pundits, including Thierry Henry, Jamie Redknapp, and Graeme Souness, believed the referee should have stopped play for the foul, despite the impressive nature of the goal.

A tour bus carrying Lady Antebellum singer Hillary Scott caught fire on a Texas freeway, but all passengers safely evacuated. Michael Barnett captured footage of the incident, showing smoke and flames from the rear of the bus. The fire started after a rear tire blowout, and Scott later shared photos on Instagram, expressing gratitude for everyone's safety and noting that her Bible was the only item spared in the bus's back lounge.

A Scottish scientist, Dr. Adrian Quarterman, is developing a space laser technology to harness solar energy and transmit it to Earth, potentially revolutionizing home heating. The lasers would convert sunlight into energy using mirrors and semiconductors, and then beam it back to Earth. This innovation could make solar power more accessible, even in less sunny regions like Scotland. While the lasers are not intended as weapons, Dr. Quarterman acknowledges the potential risks of controlling such powerful technology. The concept differs from other space laser ideas, like the one proposed by Tokyo researchers to clear space debris, as it focuses on energy transmission rather than debris removal.

A convicted paedophile, Stephen Munden, has escaped from a psychiatric unit and is currently on the run. Munden, who has a history of sexual offences against young girls, was last seen leaving a hospital in Hampshire. He is described as having a heavy build, dark hair, and possibly no beard. Authorities have launched a manhunt, emphasizing the urgency of finding Munden due to his learning difficulties and the nature of his convictions.

A Los Angeles judge has ordered V. Stiviano to pay back over $2.6 million in gifts to Donald Sterling's wife, Rochelle "Shelly" Sterling, who sued Stiviano for targeting wealthy older men. This decision sets a precedent for spouses to recover damages from recipients of such gifts. Stiviano received various expensive items from Sterling, including cars, real estate, and even smaller gifts like a blender and a lace thong. The lawsuit followed the release of an audio recording where Sterling made racist remarks, chastising Stiviano for associating with African-Americans, leading to his ban and fine from the NBA.

Thierry Henry, a former Arsenal player and current Sky Sports pundit, has criticized the club's transfer activity and believes they need to sign four key players to challenge for the Premier League title. These include a goalkeeper, centre back, defensive midfielder, and a top-quality striker, as he feels Olivier Giroud is not sufficient to lead the team to championship success. Henry draws comparisons with Chelsea's title-winning signings and suggests Arsenal should aim for players of similar calibre. He also highlights the need for a competitive squad depth to achieve league victory.

A young woman, abused by Bega Cheese boss Maurice Van Ryn for years, shared her story in court, revealing the significant impact on her life. Van Ryn pleaded guilty to 12 sex offenses, including persistent sexual abuse of a child. The victim expressed fears about future relationships and questioned why she was targeted. She kept the abuse secret until Van Ryn was caught, after which she attempted suicide. The woman, remaining anonymous, worries about Van Ryn's release and its effect on her relationships with men. She has struggled with depression and self-harm since age 14.

Serge Gnabry, a 19-year-old midfielder, is making a comeback after a year-long absence due to a serious knee injury. He recently played 90 minutes for Arsenal's Under-21 team, marking his recovery and readiness to rejoin the first team. Gnabry, who impressed in the previous season, is optimistic about his progress and looks forward to future games.

A 23-year-old accountant, Jacob Phillips, tragically died after falling from a 70ft cliff while attempting to evade a taxi fare. He had been out with friends in Cardiff and Penarth, South Wales, but when they realized they didn't have enough money for the taxi, they decided to run away from it. Mr. Phillips, in the dark, leapt over a fence and accidentally plunged down the cliff. His body was discovered the next day by a dog walker on a rocky beach. The coroner ruled the death as accidental, stating that Mr. Phillips likely became disoriented and was unaware of the danger ahead.

A large number of holidaymakers affected by passport delays last summer have not received compensation, despite the passport agency making a significant profit of Â£42 million during the crisis. Managers at the agency received bonuses up to Â£3,500, while ministers refused to provide refunds to families who incurred extra costs or missed trips. The Home Affairs Committee chairman, Keith Vaz, advocated for compensation but was surprised to learn that only 2,191 compensation applications were approved, with a total payout of Â£203,066. The Passport Office has not disclosed the number of rejected claims, citing system failure. Ministers declined to compensate all affected individuals, citing the potential for setting a precedent. Many holidaymakers who missed trips or paid extra for expedited passports have not received refunds, including Mathew Bean and Hayley Kirkham, who lost money on a trip to Morocco due to passport delays.

A semi-detached house in Horfield, Bristol, that has been untouched since the 1930s, is up for auction. The property is a collector's dream, retaining original features like stained-glass windows, oil-fired central heating, and vintage food jars. The house includes the original bathroom, kitchen, and wood-panelled hallway, showcasing a unique mint green and black colour scheme. The three-bedroom home also features 1930s cupboards, an open-face brick fire, and a dated sink. Original tins of produce, such as Cadbury's Marvel dried milk, are displayed on a hallway shelf. Despite some modern upgrades like double glazing, the auctioneers believe the potential renovation costs might deter developers. The house is expected to sell for Â£200,000 to Â£250,000.
Colin Kaepernick started his NFL career as a backup quarterback, but after an injury to the starter, he took over and led the San Francisco 49ers to a Super Bowl appearance in the 2012 season.
Soul Food is a comedy-drama film from 1997, produced by Kenneth Edmonds (Babyface), Tracey Edmonds, and Robert Teitel, and distributed by Fox 2000 Pictures.

Anne Rice, a New Orleans native, relocated to Texas and then San Francisco. Route 495, a 3.45-mile freeway in Hudson County, New Jersey, links the New Jersey Turnpike (I-95) to New York State Route 495 within the Lincoln Tunnel, facilitating travel to Midtown Manhattan.
Telemundo is an American Spanish-language TV network, owned by Comcast's NBCUniversal division.

Damon Albarn, a musician from East London, co-founded the band Blur with Graham Coxon. Their musical style evolved from alternative rock to a blend of various genres. After their debut album in 1991, the self-titled 'Blur' album in 2001 achieved global success. Albarn's solo career began with 'Everyday Robots' in 2014, featuring collaborations with various artists and showcasing his diverse musical influences.
Mogadishu, locally known as Hamar, is the capital and largest city of Somalia, serving as the hub for many significant national institutions.
"Happiness in Slavery" is a song by Nine Inch Nails, released on their 1992 EP, Broken.
Andrew Kevin Walker, born August 14, 1964, is an American screenwriter who has been nominated for a BAFTA award.

The 2007 film 'Shooter' and its subsequent TV series adaptation both centre on the character of Bob Lee Swagger, a skilled marksman and military veteran. In the film, Swagger is wrongfully accused of murder by a corrupt private military group, while the TV show explores his return to action to thwart an assassination attempt on the president.
House is an American medical drama series that aired on Fox for eight seasons, from 2004 to 2012.

Charles Manson, a cult leader, was convicted of first-degree murder and conspiracy for orchestrating the killings of seven people, including actress Sharon Tate, through his followers. He was also convicted of murdering Gary Hinman and Donald "Shorty" Shea. Manson's songs were commercially released after his arrest.

Sean Penn, born in 1960, is an American actor, filmmaker, and activist. He started in television, directed by his father, before transitioning to film with 'Taps' in 1981. Penn gained critical acclaim for his roles in crime dramas in the late 1980s and early 1990s. He was the eighth President of the United States from 1837 to 1841, preceded by his tenure as the eighth Vice President and tenth Secretary of State under President Andrew Jackson. Van Buren played a significant role in Jackson's 1828 election and later resigned from his position as Governor of New York to join Jackson's cabinet. His resignation as Secretary of State helped resolve the Petticoat affair, leading to his appointment as American minister to Britain by Jackson.

Camden, New Jersey, is home to two prominent educational institutions: Rutgers UniversityâCamden, established in 1926 as the South Jersey Law School, and the more recently opened Cooper Medical School of Rowan University, which began operations in 2012.

Michigan is a state in the Great Lakes and Midwestern US, known for its two peninsulas and popularity for recreational boating. It is the tenth most populous state and has the eleventh largest total area, being the largest east of the Mississippi River.

Penguin Books pioneered the publishing industry in the 1930s by introducing affordable paperbacks, priced at sixpence and sold through various retailers. This innovation made high-quality fiction and non-fiction accessible to the mass market.
The 2008 film Australia was produced in several Australian locations, including Sydney, Darwin, Kununurra, and Bowen.

Billy Ray Cyrus is an American country music artist who contributed to the genre's global popularity. Excuse My French is a shared title for American rapper French Montana's debut album and an Egyptian comedy film directed by Amr Salama. The film, based on Salama's experiences, faced censorship challenges due to its religious discrimination theme.
Derek Hough starred in the 2013 dance film 'Make Your Move', a South Korean-American production with a Romeo and Juliet-inspired storyline.

"Bad Romance" is a song by Lady Gaga from her 2009 EP, The Fame Monster. The song was leaked as a demo but was officially released at Paris Fashion Week, becoming a global hit and one of the best-selling singles ever. There is also an independent drama film with the same title, released in 2011.

DreamWorks Animation has released 34 feature films, including popular franchises like Shrek, Madagascar, and Kung Fu Panda, as well as standalone hits. They also produced the animated series Trollhunters for Netflix, created by Guillermo del Toro.

Chris Eubank is a retired British professional boxer who competed for over a decade. His son, Chris Eubank Jr., is also a British professional boxer and has followed in his father's footsteps. Eubank Jr. has held multiple titles, including the IBO super-middleweight title, WBA interim middleweight title, and British middleweight title. As of May 2017, he was ranked among the top middleweights and super middleweights in the world by various boxing organizations.
Sophia Bush is an American actress and activist, famous for her roles in several films, including John Tucker Must Die, The Hitcher, and The Narrows.

Rupert Murdoch is the chairman and CEO of Fox News, a global media empire. Murdoch has control over News Corporation, now the second-largest media conglomerate, and its successors, News Corp and 21st Century Fox, after a split in 2013. His son, James Murdoch, is also a prominent businessman, serving as CEO of 21st Century Fox and chairman of Sky plc.
Gal Gadot was one of the highest-earning actress/models in Israel in 2013, primarily from her acting roles.
Creedence Clearwater Revival, commonly known as Creedence or CCR, was an American rock band popular during the late 1960s and early 1970s.
Calcaneal spurs are bony outgrowths on the heel bone that are identified through X-ray imaging.
The South Wales Coalfield is a coal-rich area in south Wales, particularly within the South Wales Valleys.
The CONCACAF Champions League is an annual football tournament for the best clubs in North America, Central America, and the Caribbean. It began in 1962 as the CONCACAF Champions' Cup.

Mary of Teck became Queen Mother in 1936 after her husband George's death. Her eldest son Edward's brief reign ended when he abdicated to marry Wallis Simpson. She then supported her second son Albert, who became King George VI, until his death in 1952. Mary passed away the following year during the reign of her granddaughter, the future Queen Elizabeth II.
The film Poseidon was a moderate financial success, generating worldwide box office revenue of over $181 million against a production budget of $160 million.

The NAACP Image Award for Outstanding Supporting Actor in a Drama Series was introduced in 1996. Omar Epps and Joe Morton have each won this award three times, making them the most-awarded actors in this category.

Human trafficking is a global issue, primarily involving forced labour, sexual slavery, and exploitation. The International Labour Organization estimates that forced labour generates $150 billion annually, with millions of victims exploited for labour, sex, and state-imposed work.
The animated film Rio, released in 2011, had a sequel, Rio 2, which came out on April 11, 2014.

Francis I was the title of two European monarchs. The first, Francis I of the Holy Roman Empire and Tuscany (1708-1765), was overshadowed by his wife, who held the real power. The second, Francis I of France (1494-1547), was the first king from the AngoulÃªme branch of the House of Valois. Known for his distinctive nose and personal involvement in wars, he fought against Charles V of Spain and the Holy Roman Empire, forming a controversial alliance with the Ottoman sultan Suleiman the Magnificent. The Italian War of 1536-1538 was a significant conflict between these two rival rulers.

Peking University, a renowned Chinese research university and C9 League member, holds the distinction of being China's first modern national university. Established in 1898 as the Imperial University of Peking, it replaced the ancient Imperial Academy and initially served as the country's highest education administration. Consistently ranked as the top institution in mainland China, it is colloquially known as BÄidÃ  (åå¤§) in Chinese.
Lemmy was a well-known figure recognised for his unique physical attributes, such as his friendly mutton chops, gravelly voice, and bass playing style.

Global warming poses a threat to human food security and habitation. It can lead to reduced crop yields, impacting food availability, and force the abandonment of populated areas due to rising sea levels.

Australia is a 2008 epic historical romantic drama film directed by Baz Luhrmann, featuring an international cast with Nicole Kidman and Hugh Jackman in the lead roles. The film showcases the diverse landscapes of Australia and tells a story set in the country's historical context.
Michael Vick is a former NFL quarterback who played for 13 seasons, most notably with the Atlanta Falcons and Philadelphia Eagles.

Canadian folklore encompasses a rich variety of cultural elements, including songs, legends, jokes, rhymes, proverbs, weather-related beliefs, superstitions, and traditional practices like food and craft-making. This folklore is primarily transmitted through oral traditions, featuring tales, proverbs, and humorous anecdotes.
The First Motion Picture Unit produced over 400 films, combining education with entertainment. Its output included training films, and it also trained combat cameramen.

James Jones is a name shared by two notable individuals:

- James Jones, an author known for his award-winning novel "From Here to Eternity," which was adapted into a film and later a TV series.
- James Jones, a basketball player who has achieved success in the NBA, winning multiple championships and consistently performing at a high level.
Humphrey Bogart is considered the greatest male star of Classic American cinema, as ranked by the American Film Institute in 1999.
Computer animation is the technique behind Trollhunters, an American fantasy series on Netflix, developed by Guillermo del Toro in collaboration with DreamWorks Animation and Double Dare You.
Shane McMahon resigned from WWE in 2009, with his resignation taking effect at the start of 2010.

Tom Baker is an English actor best known for playing the fourth Doctor in Doctor Who from 1974 to 1981, the longest-serving actor in the role. He also narrated the comedy series Little Britain and has an extensive voice-acting career, narrating commercials, video games, audiobooks, and television series.
Angelsberg is a small town located within the commune of Fischbach in central Luxembourg.

The Hanford Site is a location that encompasses a diverse range of nuclear-related facilities. It is primarily known for its cleanup project, but it also includes the Columbia Generating Station, a commercial nuclear power plant, as well as research and development centers like the Pacific Northwest National Laboratory and the LIGO Hanford Observatory.

The White House Press Secretary is a senior role appointed by the President to act as the spokesperson for the executive branch, including the President, senior executives, and their policies. This position does not require Senate confirmation but is highly prominent due to its direct communication with the media and the public.

Kentucky, nicknamed the "Bluegrass State," is renowned for its fertile soil and the Bluegrass Region in central Kentucky, home to Louisville and Lexington. The state is famous for horse racing, bourbon, coal, the historic My Old Kentucky Home, automobile manufacturing, tobacco, music, college basketball, and Kentucky Fried Chicken.
The 2006 film Broken Bridges features Toby Keith, Lindsey Haun, Burt Reynolds, and Kelly Preston, who has also starred in The Cat in the Hat and Old Dogs.
Kesha, born Kesha Rose Sebert, is an American singer, songwriter, and rapper. She was born on March 1, 1987, and previously stylized her name as Ke$ha.
On May 5, 2017, two new versions of the song 'Despacito' were released: an electronic version by Major Lazer and MOSKA, and an urban version by Sky.

Starrcade was a professional wrestling event held annually from 1983 to 2000, initially broadcast on closed-circuit TV and later on pay-per-view. It was organised by the NWA and later WCW. The 1987 event marked the first NWA pay-per-view broadcast, competing with WWF's Survivor Series. The WWE Network included earlier Starrcade events (1983-1986) in its pay-per-view section, rating them TV-MA for violence, notably the "I Quit" match between Tully Blanchard and Magnum T.A. Starrcade 1997 was the 15th edition of the PPV event.
Veeru Devgan is an Indian stunt coordinator, action choreographer, and film director in the Bollywood industry.
Star Trek: Discovery is the first series created for the streaming service, marking the return of the franchise after a 12-year hiatus since the conclusion of Star Trek: Enterprise.

Terry Crews played as a defensive end and linebacker in the NFL for several teams, including the Los Angeles Rams, San Diego Chargers, and Washington Redskins. He also played in the World League of American Football with Rhein Fire.

Excuse My French is a term that can refer to both a 2013 album by French Montana and a 2014 Egyptian comedy film directed by Amr Salama. The film is based on Salama's experiences at a public middle school in Egypt after returning from Saudi Arabia. Plan B, a British hip-hop artist and actor, was born Benjamin Paul Ballance-Drew in 1983.

A floppy disk is a portable data storage device made from a thin, flexible magnetic disk enclosed in a protective plastic case lined with fabric to prevent dust damage. It is a common and affordable way to store and transfer digital information.

"Guatemala's history from the 19th century to the late 20th century was marked by instability, civil unrest, and a prolonged civil war. The civil war, lasting from 1960 to 1996, involved the US-supported government and leftist rebels, resulting in brutal massacres of the Maya people by the military."
Forceps are handheld tools with a hinged design, used for gripping and holding items. In non-medical contexts, they are commonly known as tweezers, tongs, pliers, clips, or clamps.
The Closer, a popular cable drama, commenced its seventh and final season on July 11, 2011, following the success of its sixth season as the highest-rated drama on cable television.

Dr. Jack Shephard, portrayed by Matthew Fox, is the main character of the popular American TV series Lost, which aired on ABC from 2004 to 2010, spanning 6 seasons and 121 episodes. The show gained a significant following, with an average of 16 million viewers per episode in its first season.

Matthew McConaughey is an American actor known for his dramatic roles in various films, including The Lincoln Lawyer, Bernie, Killer Joe, The Paperboy, Mud, Magic Mike, The Wolf of Wall Street, Dallas Buyers Club, Interstellar, The Sea of Trees, and Free State of Jones. The 2012 film Mud features McConaughey alongside Tye Sheridan, Jacob Lofland, Sam Shepard, and Reese Witherspoon.

Robert Palmer was a writer, journalist, and musician. He wrote books such as 'Deep Blues' and contributed music journalism to publications like the New York Times and Rolling Stone. Palmer produced blues recordings and soundtracks, and he played the clarinet in the 1960s band, the Insect Trust.

James Lincoln de la Mothe Borglum, an American artist and engineer, is renowned for his role in completing the iconic Mount Rushmore National Memorial. After the death of the project's original leader, Gutzon Borglum, in 1941, Lincoln Borglum took charge and ensured the completion of this monumental sculpture, which had been designed and worked on by his father since 1927.

The film Underdog is a live-action/animated comedy directed by Frederik Du Chau, featuring an ensemble cast of well-known actors and voice artists. It showcases the voice talents of Jason Lee, Amy Adams, and Brad Garrett alongside live-action performances by Jim Belushi, Peter Dinklage, John Slattery, and Patrick Warburton. The screenplay is written by Joe Piscatella, Adam Rifkin, and Craig A. Williams.

A group of teenagers, including Clarke Griffin, Bellamy Blake, and others, are the first to return to Earth after a nuclear apocalypse, having lived in a space habitat called "The Ark". The series explores their experiences, as well as the stories of Dr. Abby Griffin, Clarke's mother, and other key figures from the Ark's leadership.

The Concert for Bangladesh was a groundbreaking humanitarian initiative that faced initial financial challenges but ultimately achieved great success. It raised significant funds, created awareness, and set a precedent for future aid projects, including Live Aid.
Mani Ratnam is a highly influential Indian filmmaker known for his significant contributions to the Tamil film industry and the broader transformation of Indian cinema.

The Freeport Doctrine was introduced by Stephen A. Douglas during the second Lincoln-Douglas debate in 1858, in Freeport, Illinois. The Lincoln-Douglas Debates, a series of seven encounters, featured Abraham Lincoln, the Republican Senate candidate, and incumbent Democrat Stephen Douglas. The debates in Freeport, Quincy, and Alton attracted significant crowds from nearby states due to the national significance of the slavery issue.

Easy A is a 2010 American teen comedy film directed by Will Gluck and written by Bert V. Royal. It features an ensemble cast including Emma Stone, Stanley Tucci, Patricia Clarkson, and many other notable actors.

Anne Rice, born Howard Allen Frances O'Brien, is an American author known for her gothic, Christian, and erotic literature. Her writing career started with the publication of 'Interview with the Vampire' in 1976, and she gained critical and commercial success in the 1980s. Rice was married to Stan Rice, a poet and painter, for 41 years until his passing in 2002.

Camden, a city in Camden County, New Jersey, had a population of 77,344 as of the 2010 census, making it the 12th most populous municipality in the state. Historically, Camden's population comprised mainly European immigrants during the early 20th century.
Bret Easton Ellis wrote the screenplay for the 2013 erotic thriller-drama film, The Canyons, which was directed by Paul Schrader. The film received negative critical reception.

A series of seven debates, known as the Lincoln-Douglas Debates or The Great Debates of 1858, took place between Abraham Lincoln, the Republican candidate for the US Senate, and Stephen Douglas, the Democratic incumbent. These debates occurred in various towns across Illinois.

The ancient Greeks attributed the authorship of the foundational epic poems, the Iliad and the Odyssey, to a figure named Homer. Separately, Joe R. Lansdale, an American novelist, penned a mystery-suspense novel titled The Thicket.
A former United States Navy SEAL and sniper, Christopher Scott Kyle, was murdered by Eddie Ray Routh at a Texas shooting range on February 2, 2013.

Audioslave was a rock band formed in 2001, featuring renowned musicians from the grunge and rap-rock genres. The band consisted of Chris Cornell, the former lead singer and guitarist of Soundgarden, and three members of Rage Against the Machine: Tom Morello on lead guitar, Tim Commerford on bass and backing vocals, and Brad Wilk on drums. Wilk, a prominent drummer, started his career with Greta before co-founding Rage Against the Machine in 1991, and later joined Prophets of Rage in 2016. Rage Against the Machine, formed in 1991, blended rap and rock with Zack de la Rocha as the rapper and vocalist, alongside Commerford, Morello, and Wilk.

Janelle MonÃ¡e Robinson, an American singer, songwriter, actress, and model, released her debut studio album, The ArchAndroid, in 2010. The album received critical acclaim and was a concept album sequel to her previous EP, released under her own label, Wondaland Arts Society, and Atlantic Records.
Winter's Tale is a novel authored by Mark Helprin and published in 1983.

Lake Providence is a town in northeastern Louisiana, serving as the parish seat of East Carroll Parish. The University of Mississippi, located nearby, has a diverse student body, with approximately 55% of undergraduates and 60% overall from Mississippi, and 23% representing minority groups. The university attracts international students from 90 different countries.
The series 'Flaked' was renewed for a second season consisting of six episodes, set to air on June 2, 2017.

Aaron Burr served in various political offices in New York, including two terms in the State Assembly, as Attorney General, and as a U.S. Senator. He culminated his political career as Vice President of the United States.

The Soyuz rocket was developed in the 1960s by the Korolyov Design Bureau (now RKK Energia) for the Soviet space programme. It was commissioned to launch Soyuz spacecraft, initially with 8 unmanned test flights, followed by 19 manned missions. The Soyuz spacecraft, named for the Russian word for 'Union', were designed to succeed the Voskhod spacecraft and support the Soviet manned lunar programs. This spacecraft series remains in service today.
Steve Ditko, a student of renowned Batman artist Jerry Robinson, pursued his artistic education at the Cartoonist and Illustrators School in New York City.

Rage Against the Machine, an American rap metal band, faced internal conflicts in 2000, resulting in the departure of frontman de la Rocha and the band's subsequent breakup. De la Rocha pursued a solo career, while the remaining members formed Audioslave with Chris Cornell. After Audioslave's disbandment in 2007, Rage Against the Machine reunited and performed at the Coachella Festival, marking their first performance in seven years. Their final studio album, 'Renegades', was released in 2000.

The S&P BSE SENSEX is a stock market index comprising 30 financially robust companies listed on the Bombay Stock Exchange (BSE). One of these companies is Tata Motors, which is traded on the BSE, the National Stock Exchange of India, and the New York Stock Exchange, and is a significant component of the SENSEX index.

Vietnam, officially the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, is a densely populated country in Southeast Asia, sharing borders with multiple countries. It is one of the world's fastest-growing economies and is one of the few remaining one-party socialist states.
Dreamer is a 2005 American sports drama film, marking the directorial debut of writer John Gatins.

Bhagat Singh, a charismatic Indian socialist revolutionary, gained fame for his anti-British actions and subsequent execution at a young age, becoming a revered folk hero in the Indian independence movement.

Aparshakti Khurana debuted in Bollywood with the 2016 Indian biographical sports drama film 'Dangal', starring Aamir Khan. The film, directed by Nitesh Tiwari, revolves around a wrestling competition.

James VI and I, also known as James Stuart, was the monarch of Scotland, England, and Ireland from 1567 to 1625. Despite ruling over both Scotland and England in a personal union, the two kingdoms maintained separate political institutions, including their own parliaments and legal systems. James advocated for a unified parliament for England and Scotland, but encountered challenges with Parliament during his reign.

Danielle Cormack, a New Zealand actress, is renowned for her diverse roles across stage and screen. She was part of the initial cast of the long-running soap opera 'Shortland Street', and later gained recognition for her performances in various TV series, including 'Xena: Warrior Princess', 'The Cult', 'Legend of the Seeker', and 'Underbelly: Razor', where she played the notorious Kate Leigh. Cormack's most notable recent work was her four-year stint as Bea Smith in the prison drama 'Wentworth'.
Rob Sheridan, born October 11, 1979, is an American creative professional renowned for his graphic design, direction, and photography contributions to the band Nine Inch Nails.

David Spade is an actor and comedian known for his roles in various comedy films. He starred in "Tommy Boy," "Black Sheep," and the "Joe Dirt" franchise, including the 2015 sequel "Joe Dirt 2: Beautiful Loser," which he also co-wrote with Fred Wolf. Spade has been a part of several successful comedy productions, showcasing his talent in the industry.
Angela Evelyn Bassett is an American actress born on August 16, 1958.

Artpop, Lady Gaga's album, received mixed critical reviews but was a commercial success. It debuted at number one on the US Billboard 200, selling 258,000 copies in its first week and 757,000 copies overall in the US. Globally, it was the ninth best-selling album of 2013, with 2.3 million copies sold.
John Frusciante's final album with the Red Hot Chili Peppers, Stadium Arcadium, was released in 2006. This album marked Frusciante's last contribution to the band before his departure in 2009.

Margaret Thatcher, a significant and divisive British Prime Minister, introduced Thatcherism, a set of influential policies still debated today, solidifying her legacy as a powerful political figure in UK history.

Michael Andrew McKagan, also known as Duff McKagan, is an American musician, singer, songwriter, and author. Beyond his musical endeavours, McKagan has pursued writing, contributing weekly columns on diverse subjects to various online platforms, including SeattleWeekly.com, Playboy.com, and ESPN.com.

Tom Baker is an English actor who has a diverse career spanning acting, narration, and voice-over work. He has lent his voice to commercials, video games, audiobooks, and television series, showcasing his versatility in the entertainment industry.
